headline: Good place to learn
pros:
CIBC is a good place to develop your career if you are someone who is interested in Banking and Finance Industry.

Pay is good compared to other peer big 4 banks. As company just restructured the pay for bottom and middle levels.

Although getting in to bank is bit tough but once you are in there are lots of growth opportunities. No sales pressure but lots of unnecessary paper works and back office work amd reporting.
cons:
Politics
People always are behind you 
Lots of work duplication
No proper training. They just throw you into the role and basically it is like Swim or Sink..
Lots of needless calls and conferences (virtually)

headline: Ok for short term, don’t stay more than 1 year
pros: Pay is reasonably good for entry level. Benefits package is excellent. Decent experience for entry level. Do it for a year then get out, you do not want to get stuck in this role long term, trust me.
cons: You are the bottom of the totem pole. Management piles everything on FSR’s. High stress, high sales pressure, little support from above. If you get lucky to have a great manager (rare) it might be bearable. At a busy branch you can end up dealing with upwards of 30 clients a week plus the pressure to always make cold calls.

PAY IS TRASH

headline: Opportunity to learn a lot
pros:
If the right management is in place, then it can be a very rewarding career. You have exposure to so many things from day to day banking, investing, lending- for both personal and business. 
You can build very strong relationships with colleagues and clients alike.
cons:
Training is sub-par- they need to do a better job training employees to be the experts they want us to be. 

Expectations are too high - portfolio size is too large for one person to manage effectively, which means you either don’t do a good job for your clients or in my case you burn yourself out trying to do it all.

headline: Internal processes suck... a lot
pros:
Autonomy
Flexible work hours
And not a whole lot else that other banks aren't offering
cons:
Everything
Internal processes are broken and time consuming
Technology is terrible and slow
Advisors are overworked
Expectations are unrealistic (even compared to other banks)
Promotions are tenure bases, and not based on merit
Variable compensation is gone and base bonuses are 12% of base salary compared to well over 30% (and even 100% for top performers in fiscal 2021) in the past
The "Imperial Service Offer" is heavily diluted with non-qualifying clients who burden advisors and detract from providing good service to our best clients
CIBC's mortgage business sucked for so long now everyones focus is on mortgages and we have forgotten the other parts of our business

A lot of passing responsibility to others with many departments not knowing how to solve an issue

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: Some good coworkers. Good clients.
cons: Honestly the worst job experience I have ever had. If you want to be completely overworked, constantly managing red tape, being screamed at constantly by clients and managers, having to complete impossible sales volumes and units, have no real coaching for your position, have no mental health help, managers who don't have a clue what they are doing because they are all external and never been in your role before, an awful and outdated system that is down once a week, and an experience that will eventually cause a mental or physical breakdown... this is the job for you. Avoid at all costs. I work at another bank now and it is light-years better.

cons: Sadistic management, low pay, excessive micromanagement, and unrealistic targets. If you like a miserable work environment then this is the job for you. -Clients get sent out surveys which are based on your performance and consists of 8-10 questions about their experience and if they give the company a score below 8 it does affect your stats, even if they give the agent a high score of 9's and 10's. It is all based on the company. 
-No team effort, management is extremely competitive 
-Turn over rate is high, constantly hiring

headline: Toxic environment
pros: Slightly higher pay than TD
cons:
Toxic environment, high pressure for sales , and most confusing bonus structure that you won’t even know how get it end of year. Senior advisors will dump their mortgage clients on their book , which they already got paid for it , on new advisors book, so when mortgage get paid off of transfer to another banks it comes of from your book and net sales. For example, if you bring $ 5 million new business into your book and $ 10 million mortgages get paid off or transfer out from your book, you are net sales is minus $5million ! And you have to bring another $million to just bring your net sales to $0 lol 
Funny thing is most of those senior advisors never seen and spoke to clients before , they just got paid for it!!

headline: Great job at a mediocre bank
pros:
- MICs have a flexible schedule.

- Decent overall compensation potential.

- All the perks that come along with being a bank employee (free banking, preferred lending rates, share ownership plan, group RRSPs, pension plan, health and dental benefits, corporate discounts, etc.).

- Bank supports continuing education. Employees can advance their education and achieve certain accreditations if they aspire to do so.

- Commission can be earned for involvement in selling various products (bank accounts, credit cards, mortgages, etc.).

- Many great front line employees, colleagues.

- Low level managers are generally very good, especially considering the BS they have to endure from those above them

- All-around competitive product offerings and client-facing systems are very good. This is helpful when trying to acquire clients' investment business.
cons:
- Truly awful leadership at mid to upper levels. I could write a book about how this bank is mismanaged. They always talk about "purpose" but it's obvious that the words of leadership ring hollow.

- It's clear that shareholder interests trump everything else.

- Employees are constantly scrutinized and treated as untrustworthy.

- Commission levels are pitiful compared to similar positions at other institutions. This is largely due to the implementation of the meagre base salary that the bank uses as justification for asking MICs to perform tasks that are not really a function of the role. The bank fully expects MICs to convert internal funds to managed, shut the back door on assets leaving for other institutions, build and deepen client relationships, perform client outreach, be active within the community, and much more, all without any pay or recognition whatsoever for these activities.

- Atrocious validation process and guidelines for commission pay. Leaves MICs feeling like the bank is purposely trying to avoid paying us. 

- Convoluted compensation plan that does not align with how the bank wants MICs to perform their job and deliberately excludes the vast majority of MICs from achieving maximum bonus levels, even if they achieve plan.

- MICs receive no compensation for converting internal deposits to highly-profitable managed solutions with a 30 day window for what is considered eligible new assets. No compensation for funds transferred from Simplii. $2M cap on total new assets per client. Limit of 24 months for new assets per Imperial Service client.... the list of conditions is seemingly endless. If a rule to deny you compensation for an unusual situation doesn't exist, they'll create a rule to deny you.

- Management is seemingly determined to convert the MIC channel into a telemarketing channel by incessantly harping about leads-actioning, completely oblivious to the fact the leads they provide are unimaginably bad with zero potential. Management has demonstrated total ignorance regarding how MICs are truly effective and how they acquire business.

- Technology and IT systems are the worst in the entire industry. It's impossible to overstate how dysfunctional, disjointed, unreliable, outdated and unintuitive the technology is here. Even the hardware and peripherals in banking centres are ancient by modern standards. 
CIBC intranet and Sharepoint are resource-heavy but incredibly cumbersome, difficult to navigate and loaded with outdated and/or irrelevant content. Search functions desperately need improving. 
(The Asset Management portion of SharePoint is a highlight but even that could be organized better).

- Backend processes are riddled with delays and mistakes that undermine the frontline work of staff, annoys clients and generally makes branch life difficult for everyone.

- The physical condition of banking centres - buildings, equipment, furniture, decor, etc. - is an embarrassment. Space is very limited.

- MICs must rely on overworked, underappreciated and underdeveloped front line staff to be effective. 

- Employees are not provided with effective training and education to carry out the job that the bank wants them to do. Most feel like they've been thrown into the pool and forced to sink or swim.

- Meddling compliance procedures are painful and cumbersome.

- Disconnect between CIBC core, Imperial Service, business, commercial, Wood Gundy, Private Banking, CIBC Trust and CPIC creates numerous conflicts and undermines the "one team" approach. The conversations internally always seem to be focused on how to get credit or recognition rather than how to best take care of the clients.

headline: Relationships get you far
pros:
Great facility.
Work from home options (post covid).
Friendly team members.
Team building activities.
Job opportunities.
cons: While there are opportunities for advancement. Getting them is hard because of the internal hiring system which relies heavily on personal opinions and impressions of team leaders. Work life balance is tough because schedules are according to seniority (it took me a year and a half to get a morning shift with weekends off). Which meant not being able to go to church or attend family events without taking vacation/personal days or finding someone who would want to take on a weekend shift (next to impossible).

Pay has been good in my opinion
I have always been treated fairly and with respect
cons:
There are so many outdated processes. You'll have to complete initiatives where 90% of the work is admin and serves no purpose. It's a little frustrating working here as a young person trying to grow their skillset since you can sp me so much time on "busy work". The company is very conservative and it would be great if some of the things we did joined this millenium.

But this is a really big company so I am sure my experience is not universal (for both pros and cons)

 A lot of social gatherings and activities

headline: Stay Away If You Have 10+ Years Until Retirement
pros: Nothing really to say.  About 5% of the people are good,  friendly, and smart. If you have less than 10 years until retirement this is a good place.  Because you can do the minimum and you'll coast into your retirement.
cons: By far the worst place I've worked at.  95% of the people are clueless,  frauds, followers, and unmotivated.  Pay is not close to what the market pays. Terrible benefits,  the health insurance is expensive and not the best. If you have more than 10 years until you retire stay away. Your skillset will detiorate over time,  you will become lazy, and unmotivated.  Stay away from the Technology & Operations area especially the PMO department.  They have outdated people,  processes, procedures,  and technology.  Micromanagement is rampant.. One on One's are used as status meetings and not to talk about an employees career. Unqualified lifers are moved into management positions because they are followers who have no skillset outside of CIBC , and will do what they are told.  When the head of a department studies out of office calendars and is the human spell checker,  you know your doomed, but this is CIBC and that person is a model employee.  There is no career growth.  When a business sponsor is brought to tears because he's holding up a manilla folder that has 5 years worth of information on an outdated application that was just deployed,  you know it's the blind leading the blind.

headline: Old system and slow response time to fix issue
pros:
The only good point of working for CIBC is that you learn everything as FSR.
Bad management old software.
cons:
CIBC is worst when it comes to software and pay they will pay you peanuts and expect you to do the job of 5 people. 
1. Everyday calling client minimum 10 clients a day 
2. As working in a digital center without Tellers you will have to service the clients day to day banking transactions.
3. You u will bring mortgages and do it on the worst COINS software which is impossible to navigate.
4. You will also sell Mutual funds to the client.
5. At same time you will do lobbing.
At the end of the day clients are so angry coz there are no tellers i don't know who is making all these dumb decisions in the top management.
EMPLOYEE APPRECIATION MONTH WHAT DO U GET $5 DOLLAR TIMS CARD.
Pay is so less compared to work they ask to do. 
For last 10 years, everyone is getting the same pay but they will make billions of dollars and keep increasing fees for the customers. 

I don't know who is hiring IT department they don't know s___ still running internet explorer which everyone in the world knows slowest software in the planet. 

For one business credit card they will make you fill 10 different forms how dumb can that be.
If you want to transfer funds from RRSP savings ac to Mutual fund u need to fill entire form withing CIBC.
This bank needs to work a lot on its systems and on employee pay.

headline: Fine if you aren't ambitious
pros:
- Stable
- Hard to get fired (is only really a "pro" if you aren't very good)
- Good benefits
- Decent name on resume (for some potential employers)
cons:
- There is a lot of bureaucracy standing in the way of quick progression, attitude is that you need to "pay your dues" for a (long) period, even if you are better than most at the next level
- Pay is not competitive for high performers, and you will be up against caps on increases (max 15%) each year unless you have a manager who is willing to fight the system for you. This has a disproportionately negative impact on people who are early in their career.
- Since pay isn't good, you work with a lot of people who are not/barely competent
- Since there are people who are not/barely competent, red tape and bureaucracy is imposed to keep people from messing up

headline: Overall ok
pros: The office Spaces are clean and well maintained. There is good IT support to do your work. The computers and network in general is fast so you can work efficiently. HR helpdesk is reachable and issues get resolved quickly. Payroll dept also works well so you get paid on time. People do not yell, scream or use abusive language so its very good environment to work in. There is a no scent policy so office is perfume-less and for me its a big plus. There used to be your own workspace but this may be changing as there was a open concept workplace senior management was planning on.
cons: There is a one size fits all approach when it comes to all new initiatives. It can become quite stressful as pushing back can look like noncompliance. So whatever comes down from top comes down in full force and can crush you even though its unreasonable to do what they ask you to do in the context of your work.

headline: Great place for someone with no ambition
pros: Work life balance is good, benefits are alright too.
cons:
Where to even start?

-Middle management generally have no experience leading a team or resolving conflicts. They're also extremely hands off, and by that I mean they basically won't have any idea what you actually work on because they never talk to you. 

-0 accountability. If you're horrible at your job they'll just shuffle you to another team to be someone else's problem instead of actually addressing the issue. 

-Pay is low and you're expected to do way more than what your job description entails

-Takes forever to launch anything because of all the red tape and bureaucracy.

-Horrible culture. Designers barely talk to each other, and there's no centralized place for research, designs, etc. so everyone is very silo'd. No bonding activities either.

headline: Promising but disappointing culture
pros:
- Decent pay compared to other banks
- Decent benefits package
cons:
- Deadend job!
- Actively looking to promote but seldom do.
- Covid response is unpredictable and unstable as many days we were told there were no sick days allowed despite symptoms.
- Poor support from branch level management as they locked themselves in their offices.
- Toxic culture from upper management, sales calls were often back-handed comments about performance being below 100% satisfaction. Despite the questionnaire's offered to be misleading, and confusing.
- In my personal experience, I have seen several employees including myself promised promotions and job offers within CIBC, to then "ghost" the employees and refuse to take their calls. Clearly they don't want to boost talent from within or outside!

headline: Great employer, with low mobility
pros: Excellent management and HR, problems are addressed immediately. Promotion almost always follows standard meritocratic criteria such that you can understand why people get promoted. Too many benefits and perks to mention.
cons: The main con is a big one: upward mobility is severely restricted. It's very hard to get promoted, and when you do the salary increases are minimal. This is an overall awful problem with the Canadian economy, but it's certainly easy to see at CIBC. As much as the people who get promoted, deserve it, it's very hard to get. The second great con, is how routine based all the work is. CIBC avoids creativity and letting employees think for themself. CIBC wants employees to follow strict procedures to the letter. I believe this extends all the way up to the C-suite. Everyone is working like they are on an assembly line. It's a grind.

-low pay in comparison to peers

headline: Management on Rails
pros:
- Decent benefits
- Pay isn't bad
- Opportunities for career advancement exist
- Decent opportunity if you're starting out in banking
cons:
- Overly structured employee management system
- Senior management very hit/miss and often don't know their departments well 
- Lack of support for people not working 9-5
- Nebulous contract system for management promotions which can be rescinded even after working in the same position for 1+ years
- No overtime pay for management, often asked to do work outside of contracted hours, and you are expected to keep track of and arrange your own time in lieu (often having to negotiate your own shift cover with colleagues)

No experience in handling team and junior designer were bullied in the team meeting. They never shared how long they used to work with CIBC. headline: Never working there again and don’t even wish on worse enemy
pros: Good training program for new employees and good employee support on procedures (well trained and well informed helpline that help and guide you when you have questions or need help).
cons: Everything else. Horrible pay compared to other banks for equivalent position, before taking this job inform yourself of what the competition offers, something I didn’t do and only now know because I’m working somewhere else. All they care about is cutting expenses, in my case huge branch all advisors on sick leave but me for a year and no new employees were hired to help with the load because branch expenses had to stay within a certain number. Incompetent management, refused to serve clients who didn’t speak his language (French, he didn’t speak English in Montreal lol).And don’t even get me started on the micromanaging.

headline: Good role however way too many changes to comp year over year. Not a long term role.
pros: Competitive base salary + commission*. Flexibility to work remote and on site, however strongly encouraged to work at the branch as much as possible as you cannot close business on your own you need representatives to process account changes. Good people. Supportive leadership team. Good organization.
cons:
Commission model changes drastically year over year which significantly impacts your ability to make consistent income. 

The role has evolved from encouraging independent business development to more of a call centre model where call penetration is micro managed very closely. 

Some branch leaders don't fully support this consultant role which makes it difficult to get buy-in from front line staff to get included in meetings. There is no incentive for front end staff to include you. If they would change their scorecard that may change their behaviour.

The branch you're assigned to is a luck of the draw and will play a large part in your success or failure. Not all branches are equal in transaction/meeting levels, engaging team members yet all MIC's are compared equal.

headline: Embarrassed to say I worked here
pros:
The pay can keep people there longer than would be rational. 
Striving for mediocrity can suit some people I suppose - I think some find the atmosphere comfortable.
cons:
No vision or leadership, no strategy or direction. From the top of the bank to the heads of the asset management division. 
The opposite of a performance driven culture. Brown-nosing, political savviness and saying yes a lot can get you promoted.
Not a place to build a career, no respect for the things that would make an investment management firm successful - strong research, meritocracy, culture...

headline: Always short staffed and overworked
pros:
- Benefits right away.
- Good people environment.
cons:
- Stressful having to deal with fraud and upset customers due to short-staffing constantly.
Management wonders why the lineups are so long but will not hire more people in HO's direction. They will tell you to continue to take your time and not rush if people in line are yelling and screaming about short-staffing. Consistent short-staffing and no hiring insight was one of the main reasons I left.
- Poor ergonomics. It was the only branch in the city with no seating for CSRs...
- Management does not practice what they preach.

headline: Shame on you to be the BIG FIVE!
pros: Colleagues are all very nice and friendly.
cons:
Everything

However, the management team really sucks... lack of leadership and micromanage. 
During the COVID-19, they refuse to install the glass board in each office because they said its too expensive. So hilarious!
They prohibit you to call personal day even you provide a valid reason. 

Very uncompetitive compensation compare to other FI.
Only love to provide good compensation to employees from competitors or even new graduates and treat extremely unfair to their existing employees...

Didn't provide 2-week pay when you resign but they walk you out immediately, even banks not in the big five will give that pay. What a shame!

headline: Systemic issues with performance rating and talent management
pros: Flexibility of work hours, including working from home
cons:
The employee performance rating is a sham, it's all about ticking the box
The results of the employee evaluation of management performance, ESAT is not acted upon
The hiring system is broken, especially when it comes to new people managers. The CIBC has so many middle managers that lack EQ
The culture values sycophants over performance, this is partly related to the poor people managers, but mostly it is promoted by the obsequious culture
The talent management is non existent, a lot of skilled people become frustrated with the lack of appreciation and opportunities for growth and leave. The unskilled are often promoted because they are better at managing up and they present less of a threat to their manager. The talented people who have certain deficiencies and would benefit from some mentoring, often do not receive it; although some groups are far worse than others at developing their talent.

Nobody takes responsibility for mistakes and nobody is held accountable.

headline: disappointed about nepotism
pros: great place to work if around the great people, loved working there because of everyone around except for a few individuals which is a common journey anywhere, networking and socials life was awesome where you meet lots of people and make lots of friends
cons:
- hard work and dedication sometimes goes unnoticed and unappreciated

- disappointed at the nepotism culture - as a result of which those with more relevant experience miss out. It is a sad and shocking practice that goes round. The hiring managers get away with conducting fake interviews for the sake of HR process even though they know all along who will be hired! Makes you realise all your hard work and long hours is never appreciated by some senior management the minute you complete the duration of your employment.

headline: Best for Short-Term contracts
pros: 1) Several good benefits when you are a full-time. 2) Learned a lot from employees and have been involved in a number of projects, aside from the role. 3) Lots of smart people doing processing jobs and not up to their full-potential. 4) BEST FOR SHORT-TERM CONTRACTS, and quick experience. NOT for long-term career development.
cons: 1) Too much nepotism, especially in 22 Front St location. Don't know about other locations. 2) Asked for financing my career advancement to another department within CIBC (Request DENIED). They claimed NOT in align with current role, and will not finance anything besides CSC or related CSI courses. Dont bother requesting for financing your CFA, unless you are in an investment unit or related.

headline: Great Workplace, Broken Communications
pros: Great coworker, high learning curves, good place to develop your soft skills and also learn how financial services operate. You will need to learn how to depend on yourself a lot and become resourceful in a short period of time, making future career development quite simple.
cons: A lot of miscommunications between management levels to employees. A lot of managers are inexperienced and gave wrong advice to both employees as well as customers in training as well as servicing respectively. The best way to get experiences and gather the right advice are usually to look for your own support through different communication channels provided by the Company. New ideas get shot down and questioning illogical decisions made by senior members are frowned upon.

headline: Good Work Life Balance
pros:
1. Good team culture, healthy sense of competition within Wealth Management department
2. Good work-life balance and very understanding of family needs/taking care of kids or last minute emergencies
3. Company sees me as a person rather than a number
cons:
1. Does not pay a percentage off the book - salary is basically what you get
2. Year end bonuses are 'bank-sized' bonuses, rather than typical private wealth size. Do not go break the bank thinking you'll be getting a $10K+ bonus. 
3. No clear path or career advancement within corporate structure

headline: Nepotism and Systemic-Racism Destroys an Employees Well-Being
pros: location location location location is truly all I can say and so wish I could offer more.
cons:
Favouritism with promotions to friends or those that are liked by the executives.
Lack of sponsorship and commitment to developing a diverse and inclusive culture
There was no celebration of diversity month in 2019 which explains the heading but many more examples to pull from.
People are not treated fairly, bullies continue to not be removed even when there are hundreds of complaints about an individual
So many quality people were laid off or left
Executive shuffles don't change the culture, but changing executives, making them accountable for diversity and inclusion by having it reflective of their bonus, is what is most needed to help CIBC achieve what their competitors have been able to achieve
CIBC is not diverse as they proclaim to be unless you are in lower-paid role and non-management, yes it is a very diverse culture, but not at the Executive Table

headline: Great place to grow your career
pros: If you put in the effort you can move up. Moved from teller to advisor, all certifications paid for by company, within a few years. Great coworkers (location based I'd imagine). Great ceo, feels like the company cares about employees and clients. There's pressure to meet targets, as with any bank, but it's not over the top.
cons: Salary isn't competitive with some of the other banks. You need to focus on promotions rather than competitive pay. Last couple managers have been absolutely terrible at the job, needed help from their employees to figure out systems and regulations. Hoping this is resolved soon.

headline: Frequent technology outages/ poor management
pros: Amount of vacation weeks provided
cons:
-Vacation weeks are a quick fix (bandaid) to the company’s very real problem with high staff turnover rate. People learn quickly and leave the company quickly after joining, knowing the vacation amount doesn’t make up for what’s lacking in day to day work life.

-Managers keep track of your bathroom break minutes up to what times of the day you go. 

-Micromanaging how you talk, sales pressure, call times measured in amounts of seconds

-Reviewing and getting managed on your good calls, only because client is unhappy with the company itself and not you. This is unnecessary stress on employee as the employee did the best they can and the client was happy with them. This is a management problem.

headline: The UPs and Downs of CIBC
pros:
Great training programs and team-building exercises.
Some great social events and affiliations with charities.
Great ethnic diversity at entry and first-level management levels.
Wonderful share point equity saving programs for employees and insurance benefits .
cons:
The monetary rewards are not evenly distributed below the management level.
This employer is very client hungry when acquiring the client but not very quick to accommodate when trying to solve problems. Unfortunately when front line workers, who deal with clients all day, give simple and affective solutions. They only implement the solutions years later and after a large monetary loss. Upper management very separated in reality even though a lot of town hall meetings occur.

headline: Credit Card Services - Extreme Low pay and no care for employees during Covid 19 crisis
pros: This Credit card adjudication job is Union job so there is not much work pressure and the managers do not put much pressure to perform.
cons:
1. The pay is near the minimum wages irrespective of your past experience and since it is under union,  the increase per year is 20 cents.  Yes, 20 cents!!. We might be better off working for Tim Hortons.
2. During the ongoing Covid crisis, no work from home was provided to our department. 
3. No career advancement opportunities and Managers do not help in getting other jobs within CIBC
4. They bank on desperate new immigrants who want a job to atleast sustain in Canada so do not care about employees in terms of pay or job satification.

headline: Terrible upper management, high targets, low pay

Terrible management that parrots directions without understanding or care for reality. 
Unbelievable old systems which cause issues and delays with each iteration being layered on the old system causing more problems.
Embarrassingly poor response to COVID-19.
Low pay compared to other institutions.
unreasonably high targets which force people to fake results which in turn pushes up targets forcing more to fake results.
Poor features for employees (ex. unsecured Employee Line of credit is at Prime in TD while for us it's Prime+1%)

headline: High drive but disconnected leadership
pros:
Highly skilled workforce
Interesting work 
Remote work options
cons:
Too many leadership layers resulting in contribution compression & frustration
Fragmented work practices between leaders & teams 
Inner circle promotions & too many accelerated promotions granted to professionals (mostly Directors and above) with "under 1 year" in a job making contributions & competence questionable 
HR is diligent with line of business talent management efforts but fails to do the same for its own team (so many great people overlooked, pigeon holed and told to "keep networking" on the inside to get noticed -as if doing one's job extremely well and previous experience doesn't matter - what matters is how well you impress people over coffee chats)

headline: Typical financial institution culture
pros: I have many cons but would still recommend working for this company because it is a large corporation, you can change careers within and keep your seniority. Not all experiences are like mine; some are lucky with different managers who care about their employees. Not every department is the same. Benefits package is decent.
cons:
Work/life balance definitely skews towards work. 

Managers started collecting data and focusing on this way too much and made it seem like a factory; they only looked at quantifiable stats for employees when not everything can be quantified. 

Overtime was expected everyday in my department. Even if you did this everyday, it was not reflected in your annual review. Seemed like managers wanted to keep the bonus instead of giving them out to employees. 

Salary is way too low compared to other financial institutions. Once I started looking at other places of employment with my experience, I was getting offers with at least $10,000-$15,000 more than my previous position.

-Not much love for Montreal & other region's offices, I think most of our budget were allocated towards new construction of CIBC Square in Toronto.

-Weak attempt to rebrand, our mission statement seems to be pulled from a introduction to marketing class.

headline: Be a top performer
pros: The commissions can add up if you're one of the highest sales performers on the floor. If you like the idea of having a solid base salary + commissions that can add up to a salary of 60K or more when you consider benefits, this is the place for you. It's a good job to have if you want to purchase your very first house/get a mortgage. It can also be a good job for someone who wants to retire in around 5 years and needs an infusion of cash/bank stocks.
cons: Even as a top sales performer there comes a time you will get frustrated with the lack of advancement opportunities. There's not a lot of variety in the job, it's just take as many calls as you can as fast as you can, otherwise you're "avoiding calls." There's no flexibility. Managers can get jealous and there's a lot of office politics or micro-managing that could lead to your eventual termination if you're not promoted into management.

headline: Cheap, Misdirected, Out of Touch
pros: Friendly colleagues, close proximity to grand central
cons:
Compensation is far below market and benefits are worse than other banks with operations in the US (poor 401k match, expensive insurance, etc..). Base salary is unchanged from 10 years ago and there are no annual increases, even for the top achievers. Bonuses increase, but are still 15 - 20% below market. Work life balance has decreased as the bank tries to grow in the US without hiring additional people, but refuses to compensate anyone for the increase in workload and deal flow. Management refuses to listen to anyone's advice and chooses to keep their heads in the echo chamber that consists of out of touch, old-school Canadian executives.

Supposedly CIBC's goal is to grow in the US; however, poor acquisitions and complete neglect for their capital markets business will make that pretty difficult.

headline: Stay away
pros: Ummm, let me think. Decent location in the financial district.
cons: Where do I start...no culture. You have old Private Bank people that stick together and everyone else, post acquisition that feel aimless. Really poor moral and cooperation.  Senior management communication and involvement pretty non-existent.  Terrible technology and systems. Low salary for people that work hard and have great experience but don't fall into the favored category, for which I have yet to figure out how to get there. Blinders may help. Pay way under market. Company is just on auto-pilot and not in a good way. They just don't seem to have a clue as to what they are doing. All post acquisition people I talk to are not happy campers and management acts like they should be so happy and feel lucky to work there for reasons unknown. If I were to guess, if the job market stays strong, you will start to see a lot more of talented people that were hired in the last several years leave as this is not at all what was sold.

headline: Overall, it has been a decent place to work but lack of vision and investment over the years has caught up to CIBC.
pros: There are many bright and interesting people to work with including within leadership.  Many interesting projects in the works.  Good advancement potential for a variety of skill sets.
cons:
Archaic systems and processes, and with some exceptions, senior leadership is weak and visionless.  Leads to a very scattered and unorganized working environment.
There are many long-time employees who have not evolved with the times and offer almost no substance... yet in many cases, they have become senior leaders.

headline: A kafkaesque horror
pros:
High turnover opens room for advancement,
You will not have to prospect for clients or cold call in this position,
cons:
No training when you advance.
Without training it's trial by fire and constant disappointment in your employer,
Overworked. Unpaid overtime with 10-12 hour days, 5 days a week, sometimes 6, are completely normal.
Micromanagement by management that is out of touch with what the client experience and employee experience really is and how awful it's gotten in the last 10 years since they were actually on the floor.
Clients are getting more and more used to things being completed instantly because of technology advancements elsewhere in life. Especially with banking products, which are intangible, clients expect fast results. CIBC has incredibly antiquated systems and convoluted processes that, absolutely honestly, are still in the 1990s.

headline: Plenty of changes
pros:
- It really depends on the group, some of the groups I've worked at have been great, others I would not recommend - about 50%
- I've made some good friends over the years
- There is a new facility being built, unfortunately it won't solve a lot of the core issues (although a little puzzling why incur a huge real estate cost vs upgrading technology)
cons:
To be aware if you are considering joining:
- The company is going through major changes through cost cutting. No ftes are being replaced and funding for initatives, training are constantly cut. Be prepared for more work in the work/life balance 
- There is a focus on increasing female diversity and metrics on it, as a result males are not being considered and end up leaving the company as their next step (after reviewing 50 people, 8% women left the company vs 60% men leaving)
- Everybody agrees at the beginning of initiatives and later find ways to resist the change
- compensation is at the bottom 2/5 of the major banks

headline: No Accountability
pros: Decent benefits, great pay, and amazing coworkers. New ideas are usually encouraged.
cons:
There is no accountability with poor employees or managers. A manager can have a reputation of being very verbally abusive and have 4 people (out of their team of 9) leave in the past year because of their abusive management style and HR won't do anything about it. The Bank continues to lose great employees because of the lack of action by HR.

The lack of accountability extends to IT where employees have easily lost 2 weeks each  of work in the last year due to IT issues. Email was  down for 4 days in December. Like how does that even happen at a company of this size?

The work environment is super bland since someone had the brilliant idea to paint EVERYTHING beige. Bathrooms are cramped on some floors and some people tend to miss the toilets, quite regularly.  It's quite sad... and messy. The bathrooms are also often out of toilet paper and paper towels, at least once a week.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Great place to build experience dealing with multiple mid-size companies
cons: Unsustainable workload. Managers are expected to be responsible for business development, portfolio management, risk management, administrative items and rotating priorities. Where other FIs would have at least 2-3 people responsible for the above, CIBC expects 1 person to handle it all.

Senior Management is the worst. There is no transparency, you can never give your feedback as no one listens and acts upon it. They will treat people they like so differently. Management will work for you sometimes, but will keep telling you to remember them on survey time. Worst culture I have ever seen. Management only cares about customers, not about employees.  I wish I could give 0 stars.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: I cant think of any.
cons: Honestly the worst bank to work, Employee satisfaction is zero. A lot of my peers would agree with that as well. Management does not know how to take care of their employees, hence CIBC has the highest turnover.  Your management sees you doing well and instead of appreciating your good performance, your targets are raised for next year/quarter. I used to do a lot of credit applications and we had a huge target to approve credit and people would do anything to meet targets . This included forging documents and trust me that used to happen a lot. CIBC talks a lot about being customer focused, but actually it is the total opposite, CIBC will do anything to make money and rip off their customers and yes that includes forging documents to approve credit to people who would never be able to afford it. I am just glad i am not a part of this Bank anymore. I'll give you a hint, If you are anywhere close to Regina, SK, stay away from CIBC especially the contact center. The management is so bad, and just sales oriented. If you are good with sales you are rewarded regardless of how you get there. Anyways thats my rant!

headline: It's time to get out
pros:
Colleagues are generally nice
Has a pension
cons:
Client centric, client promise is only skin deep. It's a sale job, so only number matters. You can do your best and gives the best advice then two big estates leave your book before the year end, you are in the negative.

Micromanaging- too many metrics to follow. Values quantity over quality. 15 meetings per week, tracking tool usage, compass case, RGP, IP, net worth, NPS. It's all about ticking those boxes. Sales meeting every morning to go over your meetings for the day. How many calls you have made. It's elementary school once again.

Workplace favoritism, not always the most competent ones gets the promotion/raise. High performing advisor has so much leverage, they can even close the sale and dump the client to someone else once no potential left.

High turnovers, organization has been cutting jobs on CSR, FSA, AMCE and etc. Majority of the staff transitioned from PC Financial had all left due to lack of support. When banking centers get changed to digital advice center, staff members are given one week training all on how to handle objection. No actual training on how to do wire transfers, foreigns and etc before they take out all the tellers.

headline: Your happiness will die in 3 months
pros: Getting a bi-weekly salary above minimum wage. That's all there is really.
cons:
This is for any potential CSRs - if you got accepted stay there for the first 3 months of training to collect a cheque and then RUN!

Let's go through the journey that existing teammates and those before us have gone through. First you start your training playing wonderful games for team building; cute children's games that pit your teammates against eachother. You learn about how management loves to boast about different teams one-upping each other. You have wonderful long lunches and breaks. You sit in front of a computer and read all day over procedures. When you start your job shadowing and get a taste you quickly realize how much a facade everything is. The procedures you read are still not sufficient enough for you to understand how to deal with client's accounts. But everything is okay because you deal with basic procedures. And look at that nice cheque that the union snatched some of your money from. Look at that cheque that the other 4 major banks would give you a higher dollar amount but alas, you are at CIBC. Remenber all the amazing competitive benefits that again, the other 4 major banks would outperform.

When you are inducted to the next level, there are high risk procedures involved. You are pulled back into training for a WEEK and then are thrown out back onto the floor to perform complex procedures. Management tells you that a support leader must watch over you while doing these procedures. But you'll have one, if you're lucky TWO, to handle a whole team of people which can be anywhere between 13-25 team members.

When you get a couple audits for performing procedures wrong. They'll tell you that your probationary period will be extended. If you find yourself late one day due to the transit system, they'll mark you late (even one minute late). If you fall sick you will have a sit down with your manager and upper management about your attendance. They will call you incessantly even if you're in the hospital. They must hear your voice.

Now when you're there expect for everything to fall apart before your eyes. You go to the washroom too much because you drink the recommended amount of water? They'll watch you. You decide to take your time while servicing clients? They'll say you talk too much. You decide to speed things up? You're too fast; you're not promoting enough useless services. You were told one thing about how to perform a procedure? You do what was told to you like a studious worker - now you're not empathetic enough. Or why didn't you offer them free money for the abuse you take? Someone is calling you useless? You can warn them and hang up but you can't really. So you'll end up crying. 

You'll then start to remember the signs given to you during training, your trainers, agents on the floor of how horrifying it is to work in CIBC. You'll see people come to work when their children are seriously ill. You'll find out after a year a team of 19 can become 1 or 2.

All the while you're sitting in front of your computer looking at how outdated the procedures at that even 'til this day you can't perform a PIN reset over the phone unlike the other 4 MAJOR banks. You'll realize this when you're apologizing for old systems that can't do much. Or when clients call in yelling because CIBC is investing in ipads and humanless branches instead of getting some real powerhouse engines, forward think engineers, programmers, data analysts to change the way the bank is perceived. Maybe you'll realize when you're popping pills for anxiety, or when your coworkers drop like flies, or when CIBC is the fifth bank on the top 5 list.

Heed this warning.

headline: Customer Service Representative - Credit Cards
pros: Good benefits/ insurances. Functions here and there with free food! Credit card/ debit card perks!
cons: Coming to this job, I was very excited to be working in a bank! But let me just tell you this.. ALL the reviews on this website are all true. I have never felt so low on my mental health because it has taken a toll on me with this job. Yes, they “train” you with procedures BUT they do not tell you how to actually solve issues and they do not prepare you mentally. Clients call all the time and most of them are angry so you get verbally abused everyday and they do not tell you these things. You kind of just have to deal with it on your own. You need to have a “thick skin” to get through this job every single day and I have learned not to care. After all your training, you have coaching with your Team Leader and go over your performance and they basically tell you to be more empathetic, to say sorry even if it’s not your fault. There is so much contradictory with this job that it is hilarious, “you talk too much on the phone”, “your after call and hold time is bad”.. it’s like a never ending ride and you can never win because they always have something to say. And no matter how much hard work you do in the job, it doesn’t matter.. if the manager perceive you as something else they will go with their guts and ignore all the hard work you do. I definitely would not recommend this job. This place is horrible. I have never felt sooooo low with my mental health after being on this job. It’s like you have anxieties because you don’t know how to properly serve clients BECAUSE they do not train you properly. My advice— fake it ‘till you make it.

headline: Senior Financial Service Representative
pros: Lots of opportunities to move forward. Management really tries to make the environment supportive and fun and retention is the priority at the banking centre level. They pay for most of your credentials, which opens a lot of doors and career advancement opportunities. CIBC is changing the way they want clients to view them, and it’s less of a product push than it was a couple of years ago. They want the client to be the centre of the conversation, and targets are based on client relationship and customer experience surveys instead of the number of products you sell. This is one of the things I noticed and really liked, because I felt less like a salesman and more like a financial advisor. The mutual fund offerings are also very competitive, and in a market where ETFs are becoming more popular it’s really nice to see the mutual fund portfolios outperforming similarly allocated ETF’s and other FI’s mutual funds.
cons: Experience is very much based on the branch you work at. The compensation is low considering the amount of work expected out of you, and as a Senior FSR you are often looked to when there’s a problem that needs to be fixed so you spend time doing things that never reflect on your performance. Also there’s a big push to make outbound calls to clients, which more often than not is taken as a negative by the client. This is starting to change, but still something that sucks. All that being said, the biggest issue is the amount you’re paid vs the amount of work you do.

headline: Disorganized, stressful and horrible management
pros: Location was downtown, that was convenient.
cons:
The whole nine yards, managers are the worse, I worked in the Care department aka retentions and acquisitions. I was there for almost two years in the same role, I had about 5 different managers, no stability, the same lame schedule, not able to take basically any summer vacation because of seniority. They remove points on your reviews if you forget to give positive empathy. It happened to me once, someone said they were going on vacation (client on the phone) and I forgot to say oh wow how amazing you’re going on a trip to where? 
There is such disorganization between the call centre and the branch. The managers live in some kind of Lalaland and I even heard them making fun of people who were in sick leave and talking amongst themselves. I went to the hospital once and I had called my manager and the absence line, I respect the phone off in hospitals and they had called me 10 times that day, excessive much? I had so many problems with my pay, to this day I was supposed to get my 4%, guess what two pay scales later and no information. The complete worse, no wonder they are the worse of the top 5 big banks.

headline: What you'd expect from a large organization
pros: Ceo is amazing and has great vision
cons: Upper management are bullies with no repercussions. Disconnect between the ceo and working level. Pockets of the organization have food leaders but most only care about themselves and don't know how to effectively coach or develop.people. headline: Financial Services Representative for over a year
pros: I really can't see any in this role. I guess having a free banking and getting waived on credit cards is plus, but expected when you are working at a bank. Benefits are at par with competitors such as BMO and Scotiabank, but much lower than RBC  or TD.
cons:
- Because the role is sales without any commission or bonus, there are not much tools for branch managers to motivate  people. This turns into micro-managing to death. Since the turnover in the role is so high, there is no little to chance of getting laid unless voluntarily. 

- Achievers or rewards for delivering results are a joke. Rewards include movie tickets, max 20$ gift cards, and a lunch. 

- Clients complain about turnovers, and people who worked there long enough to move onto other branch roles admit that FSR role is the most miserable, underpaid, and demanding job. You face the client, do all the due diligence, and are paid lower than national average. 

- Pre-booked meetings are at the centre of attention. The banking industry is pushing digital/online banking, but at the branch level pre-booked meeting is mandatory. If you have your day booked for the day, you have no time helping clients at the branch. Managers will constantly disturb you for helping clients at the branch, giving you no time wrapping up or having few minutes break. 

- It seems CIBC rewards people who worked there over 20+ years at a branch level for doing administrative jobs. Branch managers have little knowledge of the process and new systems. They know how to check your outlook calendar and outbound calls/booked meetings and ask you to do more.  

- Incompetent veterans get transferred back and forth doing nothing and getting paid too much while newly hires and young people suffer. You have to pay your dues to climb even at a branch level.

headline: THE WORST PLACE I HAVE EVER WORKED
pros: There are none (except free banking)
cons:
This is by far the most toxic work environment I have ever come across.

- You're micromanaged  CONSTANTLY.
- They have incredibly high turnover and don't care at all.
- Weekly "call listenings" Where they basically listen to random calls (or calls you choose) and pick them apart asking why you didn't ask certain questions or follow their scripting. Every single thing you do is monitored. You get in trouble for going to the bathroom often or needing a second to get a drink. Every minute you are not on the phone, you're being watched.

- If you're written up you lose the chance of any bonus.
- Despite what they tell you, the only goal is to sell to clients. It's not all about client experience. They want you to sell sell sell to everyone. If it doesn't make ethical sense they still want you to sell and somehow encourage you that you're doing the right thing. 
- Management is awful. They don't care about you or your goals. They will throw the seniority card in your face every single time a new posting comes up for a different position. "There are people in this building who have been here 20 years that want that job too" and "What are you doing to work towards that position" Unless you have an in with the managers and go out drinking and do extracurriculars with them then forget the chance to move up. They will keep you in your position, promise you they will do a development plan so you will move up, make you sign it to cover themselves but never follow through on any of it. 
Also the compensation sucks here.

Sick Policy:
This is probably the most ridiculous part of working here. You get "unlimited sick days" HOWEVER if you are sick too much you get written up. KEY THING TO NOTE... ITS SUBJECTIVE. There is not an actual number of sick days to adhere to before you get written up its whatever they think is too much. Also, they don't accept sick notes or doctor notes at all. You have to call in sick to the phone line. THEN call you direct manager and leave them a voicemail. THEN wait by your phone all day for your manager to call you back to verify you're actually sick in order to be paid. It's key not to miss that phone call. 

The managers are all on a power trip. Save yourself the headache and toxic environment and...DO NOT WORK HERE. Leaving was the best decision I ever made.

- Impossible to achieve work and life balance, it is a common expectation to work overtime almost daily with no lunch or breaks
- A culture of end-less meetings, often all day back-to-back meetings
- Salary is competitive in some areas with a large disparity within the same job level and type of work; assessment does not appear to be based on meaningful experience or competency, rather, it is often based on  one manager's judgement or tenure (experience definitely matters but tenure is not always the same as meaningful experience)
- Lack of team work, and a culture of finger pointing when things go wrong

headline: I have PTSD from working at CIBC.
pros:
You get paid. 
You have health benefits the first day of employment.
cons:
Work place Bullying is frequently practiced. 
The pay doesn't compensate you for the toll on your physical and mental health working for this company. 
The sales tactics and goals for the team members ( FSR's Tellers, Admin ( yes Admin even has them) are outlandish, 
They spend millions of dollars on training staff on how to manipulate the clients of the bank into getting into more debt or how to pretend the interest rates on the investments they offer are good just because they're comparable to some other big bank.  They say its about advice but it's really just all about making money for the bank, they don't care about their customers other than to make money off them and they don't care about their employees either from the unpaid over time and the unbelievable workload.

headline: Meh
pros: Benefits, but these are standard within the industry. Nothing remotely special.
cons: It was my first time working for a major company. Its funny to see how what is taught in training isnt maintained on the work floor. From uniforms to cell phone policies, its hard to tell which rules are actually enforced. Also, dont believe anything they say aboht a "work life balance." It only seems to apply when youve been with the bank for 4+ years. If you want a decent schedule, I would tell you to look anywhere else first.

headline: Financial services representative
pros: Benefits, free insurance and downtown Halifax location
cons: The people working at the contact centre do all the work while TLs laugh and walk around all day. There is zero appreciation for the hard work and the pay is really low for the amount of work done. They see you the job. Most people have no idea what it’s all about before getting started. You will realize by passing time. Sell, sell, sell. It’s all about clients and selling. Nothing for employees. Very little online time, no fun.

headline: Last ranked bank in Canada
pros: Can't really think of anything.
cons:
- same sales pressure but much lower pay than other banks for the same position

- internal technologies  and systems are perhaps 10 to 20 years behind other banks, thus making daily work extremely frustrating and time consuming

- strategic directions are frequently changed without prior notice - an indication that there is a lack of clear focus and long term direction

- employees are frustrated with pay, incompetent back office, inconsistent procedures, lack of focus, poor internal policies, etc.  Unhappy employees lead to unhappy customers

- senior management has long ignored various issues and pretend everything is fine

-converting many branches to no-teller branches in neighborhood where the demographics composed of mostly seniors who are not adapting to new technology, resulting many client complaints. Management turned a blank eye and left it to the front line to suffer

- smallest bank in Canada so very limited career opportunities from within

headline: Great employer to work for but not a lot of opportunity for career growth unless you’re in Toronto
pros: Pay, flexible benefit packages, vacation- starts at 3 weeks plus an optional unpaid week that can be deducted off each pay which you barely miss, vacation goes up in 10th year of service to 4 weeks paid, then 5 weeks paid at 20 years. Corporate culture of trust teamwork and accountability that is actually enforced. Probably depends where you are but it is a workplace that has very little drama and positivity is encouraged and expected. They usually promote people within the company when jobs come up. Good tuition assistance and mentality around learning and development.
cons: They often give positions to people in Toronto that could easily be done remotely from other locations so there are many people stuck in the same positions for a long time elsewhere. The hours in the call centers are evenings and weekends which is hard after a while.

headline: A decent, friendly workplace

cons:
No significant downsides to the company

headline: My 10 year experience working inside Cibc’s contact centre,
pros: All is well until you meet your first prejudice team leader.
cons: Not what I would expect from a financial intuition. Before working there, I passed the building several times at 750 Lawrence avenue west in North York south of Flemington Park. I thought it was a hospital or crime scene because there was always an ambulance there.  Hr staff does nothing but side with the higher job level bubble in every incident weather wrong or right, again Hr fails. Although working for Cibc may sound appealing, from the ambulances roaches, rats to feces, predators to prejudice & Harassment. My experience working at Cibc has been simply disgusting throughout. Every front line staff member is well aware the silo mentality, Ego culture & salacious behavior at 750 Lawrence avenue west North York Ontario. Which is why they struggle with lower ratings compared to others banks. Easily my worst experience working in Canada, of all banks definitely Canada’s worst employer

headline: Financial Services Representative
pros:
- Great Health/Dental Benefits and the basic coverage is covered by the employer (additional coverage optional)
- At my location, we work no evenings or weekends
- End of the year bonus is up for grabs depending on your sales numbers 
- Short term disability paid for by employer
- Free banking & lower interest rates
- Generous vacation times
cons:
- It seems there is not a lot of training on how to use each specific program. Minimal training on investments programs.
- In branch sales roles and tellers are encouraged to direct clients to do banking online and use digital resources rather than coming into the branch but at the same time they increase a financial Services Rep's. sales targets each year when they are sometimes already unattainable at our remote location. We are telling clients to use online banking and do everything online yet at the same time are being told to meet targets of getting clients in the branch to do what we already told them to do online. It makes no sense. 
- FSR's have sales goals to meet each week and at the end of the year. I spend too much time doing small things for clients that have no effect on my sales numbers and I think there there should be an administration position in the branch doing these small time consuming things so I can focus on bigger and more productive client meetings. I feel like I get paid very little for dealing with so many different things.
- CSR scheduling at our branch is completely a mess. There is no room for more than 1 fulltime CSR in the budget and so there are a few part time positions but they are poorly scheduled.

headline: Morally bankrupt
pros: Compensation and training were quite good.  My co-workers were closely knit.  Some of the managers were nice people that hadn't bought into the cutthroat aspect of it.
cons: Crushing sales targets.  An unspoken expectation to compromise morals to achieve sales.  Rewards for taking advantage of customers.  A perverse kind of gamification for sales.

headline: Financial service rep
pros: The same standard benefits you find at any bank. They defiantly attempt to motivate you.  Good training if you can utilize it.
cons: Lowest paying bank out there.  Environment is quite hostile due to lack of support , and environment built on non friendly competition. High turn over as there is not alot of support. Robot mentality, no room for ideas . Very cookie cutter way of doing job and group think mentality. Not a positive experience. 4 new people quit in a 2 month span.  No moving up. No raises. Lack of motivation. Poorly managed. Jealousy, and just not a healthy work environment over all.

headline: Sales
pros: There are few nice staff but the rest especially, females at managerial positions are gossips.
cons: Gossip is paramount.  They give you lie tactics to prove to clients that you are helping them, whereas you know you are practically looking for sales rather than the clients' good. Very low pay for your education status. if you have a good business degree e.g. econ, bus-econ, commerce and etc  and you want to feel your 4 years in school should not be wasted, then, DO NOT WORK HERE. But if you just love to sell and do not care about your degree especially if its not in an area where you like, then you may want to stay here. Also, if you just want to sell and work here for 10 years before gaining a  good step in your career, pls stay. Better still, try other banks, e.g, TD and RBC (if you love the pay).

cons:
Horrible horrible position and institution.
I have previously worked for other banks and none of them were so unorganized like this one.
The position itself is all about the sales. Management making stupid decisions and all about pushing products to clients they don't even need just for numbers.
Salary is ridiculous for the amount of work position requires, and lower than other FI's for same position. The increases are non negotiable and don't expect more than 3% yearly. 
Bonuses are a joke.

headline: Product Pushing
pros:

Defined benefit plan has been removed but their is still a defined contribution plan and employee profit sharing options.
cons: Branch management creates a lot of pressure to sell as much in each meeting as possible, even if the client doesn’t need the products. Some managers are better mentors than others... most older managers “worked their way up” from service roles... for this reason they are not helpful to sales staff because they have no experience in that area. That being said, most of the younger managers are more educated and are from sales backgrounds so they are great.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: Some great benefits. Employee share purchase plan is an excellent opportunity to share in the bank's profitability.
cons: CIBC seems to have changed their brand to "What Fits Our Life". The strong undertaking of several years ago was to provide an excellent customer experience. Now it appears that they are forcing customers to transact business through channels other than by visiting a branch. I find that this has impacted front line employees who are being terminated with no concern for their well being; many feel discounted, under valued. unappreciated and not honestly treated. Remaining employees are being tasked with increased targets and minimal support to accomplish ever growing demands, resulting in poor morale. I feel that complaints of harassment and discrimination are quickly denied by upper management and many staff have left for health reasons, both physical and mental. To new employees, I suggest going into employment with CIBC, to not consider it as a long term career choice. Give them what you are fully capable of contributing, and take everything that you can from them - it is a fair exchange. BUT, position yourself to move on to a more appreciative employer in 5 years.

headline: CIBC = YUCK!
pros: The only thing is probably the very standard benefits.
cons:
Management are commonly comprised of:
1 Individuals who have NO post secondary education
2 Individuals who are heavy smokers and were hired as a result of mingling with other heavy smokers

RED FLAG #1  You dont want to work for an organization in which by in large people in leadership roles possess little to no post secondary education especially in this day and age where almost everyone out there looking for work has some kind of post secondary schooling. 

RED FLAG #2 Before quitting - Ive worked for the organization for over 10 years in multiple departments and divisions and 2nd major red flag is the high turnover of staff. This is easily a real bad sign of an organization when there is a constant revolving door ofstaff trying to figure a way to get out of their jobs - trust me I was one of them. It seems nice on the outside but once your in you want run back outside.  

RED FLAG #3 Over the years working there things have gotten much worse not better. Modern technologies have transformed the work environment into ultra micro managed  areas where every meticulous thing you do in a day is tracked. Essentially this trend leads to horrendous work environments where people feel like their walking all egg shells all day, every single day. What a miserable way to go through life.

No worklife balance
No opportunities to grow
No recognition for hard work

Managers with poor people skills

-Decent health and stock participation benefits
-Discount perks through the company on various things such as goodlife membership, Cheaper Phone plans, Cheap movie tickets, etc.
-Rewards for high performers
cons:
-Pay structure is not very transparent and there seems to be a lot of discontent
-There is a huge benefit being in a prime location which leads to more walk-in clients, more appointments and larger investment books, resulting to a much higher compensation
-Some management is not very supportive but it's a hit and miss
-Location plays too much of a role and creates an uneven playing field when it comes to actual performance which also leads to less pay and lower likelyhood of winning awards.

headline: Not what it seems (perspective from a seasoned retail banking sales person)
pros:
-	Flexible schedule with the ability to work from home
-	Good laptop and printer
-	Mobile and very independent
cons:
-	Ineffective and inefficient systems compared to other banks
-	Little to no immediate support for technical questions (email inbox that can take several days to respond)
-	Mistakes are constantly made by FSRs, whom are responsible for closing your deals (ie: opening the wrong type of account, processing transfers incorrectly, processing mutual fund purchases for the incorrect amount, etc.)
-	Poor training (lengthy and ineffective phone/video coaching)
-	Lots of cold calling (calling CIBC clients for ‘financial planning’ or ‘financial review’)
-	Risk of customer no-shows can waste a lot of time
-	Inefficient CRM system
-	Lots of objection handling
-	Poor validation system that causes lots of frustration

headline: Stay away from
pros: I can't think of any at the moment.
cons: Horrible culture! Managers are worked to the bone with no compensation for extra hours required to perform the basic job duties. Lots of favouritism.  Terrible Senior Management. The poorest I've seen in years. Poor processes requiring a lot of manual work and then employees and their managers are blamed for lackluster results. First there was a massive push to be productive with unrealistic targets and a lot of pressure so naturally quality suffered but Senior Management acts like it's the employees fault. The company talks about retaining talent and over works and under pays?

headline: advisory application developer
pros: stable work and not very technical all the time
cons: low pay and bad management

headline: Look elsewhere for a better job!
pros: If you like to work 9-5, you are not really required to work longer.
cons: Never worked with so many lazy and incompetent managers. This was a place that really cares about face time, wants you to come in at 8:30am, even if there isn't any work to do. A place where there are way too many meetings but no one gets anything done. A place that wastes time writing manuals about showing up to work. It's a place of work, of course you have to show up. Do you really need to coach people on showing up?

headline: Good place to work

headline: Sales/Client Services

cons: Immediate supervisors didn't always have the experience needed to lead a team. The sales goals were more aggressive year over year.

headline: Mobile investment consultant
pros:
-guaranted base of 55k for the first 6months
-unlimited income potential
-make your own schedule, very flexible
-get a laptop and can work from home sometimes
-annual cash bonus
-annual stock bonus
-you get 2branches to work with
cons:
-100% commission
-limited number of ways of making commission 
-only generate commission on new money client brings to the bank. You don't make anything for converting existing funds to an investment product
-commission is only paid on new money which is anything deposited within 6months
-clawbacks if client withdraws within 6months of investing
-The annual stock bonus is only available for withdrawal after 3years(1/3 each year).
-the amount of commission you make highly depends on your location as well as the involvement of the fsrs at your branches.

headline: Mobile Investment Consultant

headline: Senior FSR Small Business
author_position: Senior Financial Service Representative Small Business
pros: You get to work with wonderful people.
cons: They will work u to death!! Worked at busy branch did the job of two people. Very little thanks. It becomes an expectation that u work later with no pay. It's not said but just assumed, management banks every extra hour that they work and takes the time off as additional vacation  while u are not paid for the extra time, in Alberta there's a lot of bullying with management. They can get away with just about anything without being reprimanded. I left to move to a position that I waited for them to post  for a year. They cut off all of my benefits that day without even telling me. CIBC is the worse place to work!!!

headline: MA Assistant

Don't expect to leave on time
Lots of false promises made by the MA (separate from CIBC)
She cancelled your shift at 11pm the night before then expected you to come in on your day off that was a couple days away.
Schedule was never fixed and it was expected you worked past your cutoff time.

headline: Financial Services Representative - Outbound
pros: The three months of training. Don't hold your breath past this point, you'll be beat down with sales targets from day one.
cons:
Where do I start? The uneducated "Team Leaders", adherence, the inhumane conditions of being tied to your desk by a headset, the unethical practices of predatory tied selling... The list goes on and on. 

And lastly, I leave you with the Dilbert principle. The Dilbert principle refers to a 1990s theory by Dilbert cartoonist Scott Adams stating that companies tend to systematically promote their least-competent employees to management (generally middle management), in order to limit the amount of damage they are capable of doing.

Couple that with the Gervais principle, Gervais Principle, part of which is the idea that people at executive levels in large companies systematically promote incompetent but enthusiastic people to middle management as useful scapegoats. Whereas people with possible executive talent jump from the lower ranks to the exec level, bypassing the middle morass.


And you have CIBC Outbound in a nutshell!

headline: Have not worked for a worse company yet
pros: I guess as any other bank it's hard to get terminated but that's about it.
cons: Worst management I have ever experienced, no regard for employee satisfaction or customer needs. Sales goal is valued over anything else. Multiple result boards, trackers and daily emails, hourly micromanagement, failure to understand challenges. Even if the goal is met there is still pressure to work at one's redline.  If I knew the conditions of employment before starting I would have never accepted this job. Absolutely no communication and collaboration between departments which makes day to day work hell. Also, I am speaking from comparison after working at another financial institutions.

headline: Co-op Student
pros: There were lots of events happening in the summer of 2015, such as the PanAm games, which CIBC hosted. As a result, there were lots of perks available even to students which made the experience very fun and inclusive.
cons:
The director at the time equated success with the program you were enrolled in at school; if you weren't in STEM, they would never give you any real responsibilities. They also would make unnecessary comments, such as: "I'm going to team you up with this management consultant because she's a female in the workplace and so are you". How about the fact that she was successful and seeing as I did get the job, I was a perfectly suited candidate for this company as well? Ridiculous.

I'm also giving culture and values 2 stars because the company was transitioning to a new CEO and the culture was being rebranded from risk aversion to growth and expansion.

headline: Good pay and benefits, but if finance is not your favorite field it gets boring very fast.
pros: Good pay, benefits and reasonable amount of time off. Paid training for a month, which gives you an extensive knowledge of bank products and financial base overall.
cons: Schedules stay bad for the longest time. Hard to get a good shift, unless you've worked there for a year and a half/two years. Not all the people in the management positions are actually good leaders, which makes it pretty hard for their employees. Competitive environment with little incentive other than the money you get. Lack of gender diversity. Pretty much a "bro" environment.

headline: CSR
pros: It is a good place to start your career, very friendly environment, can learn a lot
cons:
They have poor philosophy with regards to clients, you cannot take your clients for granted in an industry such as this. They smother innovation and drill front line staff to shove it down customers throats, no other bank does this. They call it "digital education" but management just wants to see less transactions made from tellers and that's basically the bottom line as they look to get rid of tellers. It was awkward because clients were aware of it but you still have to get them to not use tellers for their transactions otherwise the manager of client experience will give you the stink eye and hound you every time you let them use a teller instead of getting them to use the ATMs. It is a convenient way to do your banking I agree however the approach  is very aggressive. My parents have been banking with td and rbc and I have never seen anyone there declined customer service or get pushed to use the ATMs in that manner.

Also poor compensation compared to the other top banks, lots of stress, and lots of micro management.
