headline: Worst job I've ever had
pros: Free banking, decent pay & benefits
cons: The training process lulls you into a false sense of security. You spend a month in the classroom learning how to navigate the most unhelpful, unintuitive computer systems ever. It's all long lunches, potlucks and team-building activities in the classroom. When you do finally get out on the phones, it is a brutally rude awakening. Every minute of your time must be accounted for. Bathroom breaks are discouraged. You get hundreds of company e-mails every day and are given no time to read through them. Management comes up with weird games that pit employees against each other, trying to one-up each other's sales. You are made to listen and critique each other's phone calls. The hours are incredibly long, lunch break is only 30 minutes, unpaid. If ever - god forbid - you're sick, you have to call your manager and then have your phone next to you so that they can call you back and speak to you. They do this to try and determine if people are actually sick. It's incredibly dehumanizing. I've heard stories of supervisors creeping employee's social media accounts and building cases against them if they think that they are abusing the incredibly strict sick day policy. Part of the training process includes uncovering weaknesses and exploiting them - they call these "discovery questions". They engage in predatory lending practices. Employees are disciplined for missing opportunities to sell people credit products, even when it's clear that the person has no use for it or would not be able to responsibly manage it. Absolutely the worst bank. I quit three months in after having to go on antidepressants due to extreme anxiety and depression, and I'm not the only person to have this experience either. I quit without even having another job lined up because I could not even set foot in that place another day. Turnover is extremely high. They hire 200-400 new employees every few months because so many people leave.

headline: Average at best
pros: CIBC offers a competitive salary and benefits compared to its industry. Training is encouraged to be taken to further your career. Culture and diversity is very evident in the makeup of the organization. Organization is very active in the community (i.e. sponsors a variety of community events)
cons:
Constant organization churns that inevitably leads to layoffs. Organization does not seem to have a long term strategy and is highly reactive. Over the last few years, CIBC has taken a lesser role in developing employees (placing the responsibility on the employee instead). CIBC is very process oriented organization to the point where there is more paperwork to fill out then the work itself. 

As an employee it can be difficult to take pride at this organization for the following reasons:

1. Has fallen from #2 to #5 Canadian Top Bank (with no definitive plans on how to reverse its drop)
2.  Marketing is questionable (i.e. their spokesperson is Percy the penguin)
3. The least diverse bank (compared to its peers) - primarily Canada even with recent acquisition of Private Bancorp.

headline: Robot job (CIBC corporate)
pros: Major company, annual bonus for full-timers, culture is to leave work at 4:58 pm. Free bank account.
cons: Everyone hates working there. Three-tier system of employees including full-timers, consultants, and other employees (students, co-ops, "outsourced" Indian workers who work in the Canadian office for some legally questionable reason). As a contract worker, I was paid slightly above minimum wage, with no holidays, sick days, or bonuses. When I got sick, I couldn't afford to take the day off work, so I enjoyed spreading the virus around to everyone else on my team. Employees  are only interested in protecting their jobs, not in actually doing meaningful work or making processes more efficient or effective. Our office was closed due to security reasons, but I did not have credentials to work from home, so I was required to risk my safety and go into the office if I wanted to get paid, even though I couldn't do any of my work because the people I needed to meet with were working from home. If you like Catch-22, you will love this place.

cons: Micro managing, ACHIEVERS (always the same winners)

headline: Good for shareholders, bad for employees
pros: great benefits and the new(ish) work from home model helps with the work-life balance if that's what your primary focus is.
cons: Pyramid leadership structure that keeps getting narrower and narrower at the top.  Sales staff is kept very happy, rightfully so, but ppl at cost center are far more expendible

headline: Review
pros: Promote from within. Profit sharing plan contributions. Positive working culture
cons: Slow speed of execution for projects/HR initiatives. Rigidity of corporate structure

headline: CIBC is a decent place to work
pros: Good people, interesting projects.  Dynamic CEO.
cons: Salaries lower than comparable roles in other industries

headline: Financial Service Representative
pros: amazing, comfortable work environment, the management is not up your throat all the time asking you to push sales as they are focusing more on customer satisfaction-- thats not challenging at all -- theyr just asking you to be nice to the customers
cons: Some team leaders and employees seem too obsessed in keeping a tight knit community and not wanting to associate with employees outside of their team

headline: DECENT PLACE TO WORK AT
pros: Not the best place to work at, but it's definitely not the worst. Would recommend getting CSC OR IFIC before.
cons: The pay is not the greatest. I know people at other banks who make a lot more than me. There training is okay, but it could be better.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great work culture and transparency
cons: None that I can recall

headline: Manager, commercial banking
pros: Good conditions and very good interbank communication and collaboration in the commercial banking division. Possibility to show your own potential and grow within the organization.
cons: No real cons. Everything is at least averagely equal to industry standards. Good average quality of infrastructures.

headline: costomer service rep
pros: Enjoy dealing with costumers,  also the staff that i worked with was very friendly and we had lots of staff outings
cons: Pay was not very good and often forced to meet quotas that were not very realistic

headline: senior customer service rep
pros: enjoyed to be in CIBC, great environment, good experience. I got and I still get knowledge of banking and new methods and techniques
cons: foe some people is a place to move on , for many no room to grow, depends on your manager, you should get the chance to be your manager's favourite to grow

headline: FSR to Branch Manager
pros: The yearly salary was overall higher than average for the industry for the job function. Except for branch manager which was about $25,000 less in the industry.
cons: I was taken advantaged of in ways that were later replicated in the company and I was not remunerated for my invention. Also, I was battered around emotionally and psychology through insults to my work, my body and in turn trying to be patient amongst some really mean people caused me to be depressed and disinterested in a lot of aspects in life. Losing my job showed me how much I was taken advantaged of. I am still out of pocket.

headline: Operations, Collections
pros: The people that you work with are the best part of the job. Good locations also
cons: You are just a number in the company.  No real change can come from one person

headline: management experience in the IT field
pros: exciting and challenging place to work
cons: work life balance is compromised due to many projects on limited budget

headline: Manager
pros: Great time to be at CIBC - enjoy the client and employee centric culture and opportunity for career development.
cons: Need to be willing to work in fast paced environment and be flexible and positive about change.

headline: Jump higher. Higher. Higher.
pros: An unparalleled hands on learning experience with enormous opportunity for professional growth and advancement. Build your own brand or advance within the company.
cons: Unrealistic expectations, micromanagement, lack of dedicated mentorship. Unrequited teamwork. Always chasing your tail.

headline: Analysts
pros:
-great pay

-not a lot of direction

headline: A job is a job

headline: Great Company

headline: Good dose of corporate
pros: Good first job for a graduate or part timers. It's a good chance for young people (or older) to get a real taste of dog eat dog. It'll make you harder and sharper.
cons: Low opportunity for growth (no one I knew advanced unless they had a mother or father already working for the bank 20+ years to put in a good word for them). EXTREMELY low pay especially for customer service reps in the industry. Terrible hours. If an employee tells you for religious reasons they can't work on a Sunday, please don't force them to especially when the customer service team is basically made up of part timers who can fill in.

headline: Canada's loser bank

cons: Too many of the current employees who have been around forever hinder innovation because they're so stuck in their old ways of doing things. Compensation is below market value and middle management has zero leadership skills. Everyone is far too concerned with making themselves look good to the SVP's & EVP's and so they don't really care about the development of employees which is a shame considering that the bank has such a great CEO

cons: Poor mentorship and leadership from geound level.  Employee or Clients are now just numbers. Leaders are unprofessionals and do not understand their roles and responsibilities. Everyone is just looking out for their progression. You will find unethical practises at all levels.

headline: financial service rep
pros: good working environment and great colleagues
cons: none none  none none none

headline: Great working environment
pros: if you are looking to work with finance or capital markets and IT, this place is for you
cons: On the cons side I'd say a bit of a red tape makes days a bit difficult.

headline: Financial Services Representative
pros: Decent benefits and discounts on products and services.
cons:
Branch level management needs to be monitored more.
A bad branch manager can really ruin employee morale.

headline: Senior Financial Advisor
pros: Offers a good defined benefit pension plan and excellent health and dental benefits. Matching RRSP contributions up to a certain percentage of your pay.
cons: Very high sales pressure from management to achieve unrealistic and always increasing sales targets. Its like being a used car salesman. The company talks about customers and employees being important, but in reality, only sales count. Unless you are consistently exceeding sales targets, your job will be threatened and you will be put under constant stress, anxiety, ,mental harassment and psychological pressure that is toxic to your health. Lots of unpaid overtime is required. You will have to do the work of two people. They will squeeze you for all you are worth.

headline: Unfocused
pros: Good working environment, if luck to work in a new branch, or a quiet office. some offices have no privacy.benefits are ok
cons: Micro  management, takes up  too much time, have to report every day, instead of calling or seeing clients, some managers are unable to coach or don't want to, and then get stressed out if behind target, and take it out on the staff, the bank seems to change direction every few years, seems unfocused.

pros: People are great to work with as always

headline: Working as a teller, handling cash and customer requests

cons: Company is headed towards a new change by cutting down hours, which is creating longer lineups. Clients are frustrated and complain a lot.

headline: Compensation is not comparable to Other Banks
pros:
-Meet great clients
- Tuition Assistance for career development
cons: Management attempts to keep people in their current position for a long time, even if they are performing and prepared for development. The compensation is not comparable to other banks and credit unions. Expect to work overtime on a consistent basis, go above and beyond your job responsibilities without proper recognition or compensation. Management is very vested in their own interests. No real structure for compensation, difficult to measure performance and justify pay increases. Bonuses are low and only paid once per year. They attempt to justify compensation by encouraging employees to remember the "total compensation" which is really just $10 off coupons available through workperks and benefits similar to (or worse than) any other company. They attempt to push the idea that everything is "for the client" but sales targets prove otherwise and employees are encouraged to sell more and more products every year, that clients don't necessarily need. Employees are disciplined for not meeting weekly and annual targets.

headline: Horrible Work Experience in the Branch
pros: If you're a person with no morals, no conscience and no shame, you'd fit right in with the culture!
cons: I worked at a branch - there were always power/system shutdowns, only 2-3 tellers as they want to cut down cost and have customers use iPads to do banking, Financial Services Representatives badmouth and gossip about customers, customers' info aren't kept in confidentiality, technology is  obsolete at CIBC!

Also new hires are always new immigrants who barely speak English or know how to do the job, I guess the company just cares about saving money instead of experience.

headline: Exausted and it's not ok...
pros: The pros of this institution would be the employee sharing plan with solium.it is amazing. There is great insurance benefits as well as recognition for hard workers. It's becoming more like a team environment and it's becoming a lot more client focus. You have a lot of tools to help clients and you sometimes have to think outside the box which is great and your team will support you.
cons: Cons of this institution is that there is favoritism for certain employees and they also believe you shouldn't call in sick. Even though the number one rate of suicide is from call centers. They don't believe in mental health day and also give you a hard time if you call in sick. Surprisingly because germs travel fast in a call center,they prefer you being in at 50% health then 100% and they blame the call volume on people being sick instead of under staff.at this job,you are dealing with people's accounts so you need to be at your 100% but they forget your human and it happens that you need to recharge.instead complement your staff who aren't sick but don't punish someone because there immune system is low.understand that people are different.every client is different and so are your employees. The schedual goes by seniority so forget the 9 to 5 Monday to Friday dream job. They want to be client focus but forget completely that the employees are clients as well.

headline: All negatives because of the team and the managers
pros:
- if you're looking for a 9-5 job with no work flexibility, this company is ideal for you
- good benefits (comparable to other banks)
cons:
Depending on the team you end up on, the experience can be horrible. On this team, there was massive favoritism, no opportunities to advance, no opportunities to learn new skills, indirect bullying and micro management. 

Even when these issues were brought up in employee surveys, employee reviews, hr interviews, ultimately no changes were made causing the team to fall apart in less than a year. 

There are also no opportunities for work flexibility. This is true of a lot of departments at cibc not just this team. Other teams have better people managers but none of them provide work from home options, compressed work weeks or shortened work weeks. The company as a whole promotes work flexibility depending on the department but the manager mentality in the majority of departments is too old fashioned to allow it.

Advice to people getting interviewed: ask questions about the team: is it team work oriented? Do team members share experiences and knowledge? Does management regularly acknowledge hard work? Does hard work get rewarded?

If your In the service team you are being eliminated and there is no appreciation despite all the hard work they do. They are trying to phase out tellers despite the high demand.

headline: Anti-Money Laundering Analyst
pros:
Okay benefits.

No uniformity. 
Culture of distrust and suspicion. 
No communication or crossed wires of communication. 
Very poor onboarding.  
Mediocre staff. 
For a job that requires no collaboration and is all computer based, they're still forbidding people from working from home. Unless you're a director. Or a favourite. 

If you don't drink the "company kool-aid", you will be the victim of a witch hunt.

headline: Great Employer! Lots of Opportunity

cons: Some of the premises and technology needs updating. In all fairness the industry is changing so quickly that it is expensive to change too quickly. Investment in software and facilities and tools will continue to bring CIBC to the top.

That kind of pressure is not good because it just makes workers feel bad about themselves. Everything is not a contest. Also the manager was rude all the time and didn't know how to handle sensitive situations. The workers are clients too so show some respect.

headline: Talent Attraction (Recruitment) team is being suffocated
pros: Employees in HR and Recruiting are knowledgeable and hard working, willing to help, resourceful.  There are many subject matter experts available, but they seem to be out of reach for the daily activities of the recruiter to help them do a better and faster job.
cons: Too many processes and unnecessary projects that do not help Recruiters do their actual job, and slows them down more from doing their job.  The culture has changed alot in the last year, and all for the negative. Good people have been cut, the office bully with no positive skills has been given the highest award possible, and people are afraid to look even look up from their desk, never mind speak to each other because they will get accused of gossiping and then punished.  The volume recruits are being given is uncomparable to any other banks, and managers sweep under the rug how exhausted and overworked their employees are, and worse, they mentally and emotionally punish them. Which is interesting considering that many senior managers and director and fairly new to the organization, and their level of actual recruitment is minimal so they don’t know how to do their job, but they know exactly how to play politics with the VP so they themselves look look.  Nobody has been promoted within the team or even gets to move internally to another team, which contributes even more to the zero motivation the department has reached.

headline: If you're a people person, the FA role is for you
pros: Truly satisfying if you're truly into helping clients with their finances. You get to know your clients very well, and you could have a healthy salary if you get out there and get business. And you have a base salary to get you through the tough years. Colleagues were always great.
cons: Other than selling and servicing customers, there are other targets to meet, such as calls and meetings. Overwhelming if you have a lot of servicing as well as sales and unit targets. Not impossible though.

headline: Good company, mid level execs lack skills
pros: Diverse, innovative company with desire to excel. Focus on client experience is a breath of fresh air. Company is involved in a a lot of charities which is also a matter of pride for employees
cons: As I said mid-level execs lack skills in what they do. Too many internal hurdles - often feels like a game of football ... if you have the ball (are leading an initiative), everyone jumps on you (with Nobel intentions but) causing hurdles and failures. In the supporting services there is no clear outline of who does what ... you would find multiple people doing the same thing and wanting to be part of (often with divergent views) what you are leading. They are going through lots of reorg, so recommend wait till 2018 or so before jumping on this ship.

headline: Bad politics, bad training
pros: Clock-in then clock-out. It's pretty easy when you know what you're doing and are on the good side of management.
cons:
Very unorganized company, no one really knew what was going on, it was a very just-get-through-today type of mentality. No concern with trying to plan for the future. 

High turnover: most people won't be there for over two years.

The training was laughably bad. 90% of it was going over regulations and learning how to smile instead of going over how to use the outdated DOS-based computer system that we have to use everyday.

headline: Call center financial services

cons:
Call volume was non stop for the whole day.
They were very strict with talk time, you have to serve each customer average 5 minutes or so or no bonus. If you do one thing wrong in a call it could mean your whole quarter's bonus would be gone, with no warning. Very tiring and stressful sometimes. Management very strict at times, no enough washroom breaks. Getting paid decently, but working like a financial sweat shop.

Turnover is high, people quit or get fired easily due to schedule and  quarterly invectives are nearly impossible to obtain.

headline: CSR
pros: Fun work environment, great staff

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros:
An extremely healthy company (in terms of profits) with opportunity to grow (sales focused roles)
Stable company with plans for the future
Free daily banking (must have a CIBC account as an employee)
Employee recognition days (lunch often provided)
OK benefits
cons:
HR will tell you CIBC fully covers any education required to advance your career within the company during the interview process. I applied and completed my IFC course only to find out that this is not true. The reimbursement is to the Regional and Branch managers discretion. I was a top performing CSR and only received partial reimbursement. 
Often left short staffed without any assistance on the frontline from management or financial representatives (even though they are available in their offices).
Scheduled hours can change at anytime time, for any reason and you are obligated to fulfill those hours. (Evenings and weekends)
They have reduced the number of hours in many branches for CSR employees effectively replacing full time positions with part time roles even though CIBC makes substantial increase in profits quarter after quarter, year after year.
This is a role that management openly states is being phased out.
Management knew a lot about finance, investments and how to push sales but knew very little about people management. You may be given poor or very little advice on how to improve. (As a previous manager with another company I had experience reading score cards, my manager was unsure how to read or present mine, so I showed him/her).
You are trained on how to handle a robbery situation and let's just say the procedure does not have the employees best interests in mind. 
Vacation requests must be given in advance (seniority in the company gives you first choice), December is usually blacked out for all staff. (in reality it only applies to frontline CSR's).
Your performance will be heavily measured by your ability to refer clients to Financial Service Representatives (In order to obtain a successful referral, the FSR must obtain a sale from the client)

headline: financial service ambassador
pros: good pay & benefits, good working location. Nice offices and work space.
cons: Lots of politics involved. terrible work life balance, terrible management,

headline: Amazing job
pros:
The best organization ever, trust, teamwork, accountability.
Great opportunities to grow with the company.
Great experience and heavy foucs on client exp.
cons:
There is no downsides of working for CIBC.
CIBC will become a part of ur life.
In any company on earth if ur doing good, u will get good for sure.

headline: Very good place to start your career

cons: Regular overtime, not paid, very sale oriented even though the company said its the client service that is in focus, they will press you to go over targets. Saturdays are working days  and your other free day is not determined, for people with families it could be hard.

headline: csr
pros: Good experience to get into the financial industry

headline: Branch Manager
pros:
Strong vision to be first in class in building client relationships

headline: Outsourcing is here to stay
pros: My colleagues are really knowledgeable, and we really learn and help each other.  Management is collaborative, but when you go higher up to Director, Senior Director and especially Vice President, they are too removed from the day to day job and responsibilities, so they don't know the details of our jobs and projects.  Defined benefit pension, but maybe not for long.
cons: EVERYTHING is being outsourced currently and in the next 2-3 years.  2,000 jobs lost so far this year, with hundreds more for the rest of this year, and to be repeated for the next few years.  The CEO promised to save $600 million, and no surprise the quality and morale have already been hugely compromised.   If you are looking for a job in Finance, Technology, HR, and soon Marketing, Admin, you may be able to find a job here, but within a couple of years it will be outsourced to an external vendor, who will then offshore it to India.  Apply at your own risk.

headline: Senior Credit Risk Analyst
pros: - Good opportunity for individuals just starting out with their Careers

- Internal politics

headline: CIBC

headline: Sales and Services Specialist
pros: Salary: 17.75 per hour, unionized environment, good benefit
cons: You have to meet all your targets: accuracy, sales, quality, etc if you are planning to move up in your role. It is difficult to move from this role to other roles at CIBC despite all the promises. Watch out! Don't waste your life if you are not meeting the targets and you are promised to do better so you can move up. It is a Joke!

headline: Sr Director

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros: Excellent benefits - health and employee banking offers etc, competitive salary, opportunities for growth, lots of training opportunities, employee share purchase plan
cons: Formal and very professional; long hours

headline: Financial Advisor
pros:
- the only real pro will be the knowledge, experience and workhorse mentality that you will gain from working here 
- if you're able to succeed in this environment you will be a rockstar anywhere else and will actually be given the proper recognition and pay to go along with it
-great support from financial planning consultants and trust department
cons:
-unealistic targets with no material backing as to how they are determined. Huge variation in the targets of similar portfolios in your area for no apparent reason
-many branch managers have little to no finance or investment experience and are suppose to be coaching financial advisors to be more successful in these areas
-frontline staff is severely cut and the remaining sales staff is suppose to step in and take over deposit transactions etc which takes up a lot of valuable time. This is not taken into account with regards to breakaway expectations/targets that were rolled out when branches had ample csr coverage. 
-in addition to above the goal of CIBC is to push clients to online platform and out of branch... Yet fsrs/advisors are being measured and told to bring more and more clients into branch (to show meetings/sales) for things that can be completed over phone or online.
-they roll out new software "compass" and new system updates but all it does is slow things down, bog up the sales process and make everyone seem incompetent because of all the bugs and issues that haven't been fixed. Anyone who has real sales experience and who has been properly trained does not require a program to recommend sales opportunities. 
-leading into next point... TRAIN your employees. So many fsrs/advisors are giving FINANCIAL advice to clients yet don't even comprehend what they are talking about. This WILL catch up with CIBC and its reputation as a reputable bank.

headline: CIBC
pros: Good work life balance,client focus service
cons: Need more investment in Technology ,operating systems are unnecessarily complex

headline: Senior Financial Services Representative
pros: Employee Computer Purchase Programme, staff rates on lending products, fairly rapid advancement.  Training programmes were quite enjoyable, albeit conducted at irregular intervals.  The company will pay for additional credentials as well as upgraded education for employees.  This is an acceptable job for someone fresh out of university, but does not offer long-term prospects.
cons: I was offered the position based on investment based knowledge and education; however no focus is placed on investments at the retail level.  All focus is placed on the ability to sell credit, even to those who do not need/may not be able to service it.  Advice given by other staff members is often incorrect/inappropriate/uneducated.  The company only pays attention to staff errors when there is a potential for media exposure.  Attractive time off package, but this is expected to be booked up to a year in advance, with all time given to senior staff first.  As most branches have a skeleton crew, this means vacation is often forced when you do not want/cannot make the most use of it.  Staffing levels also result in inconsistent days off.  It was very uncommon to have two scheduled days off at a time, and nearly unheard of having a proper weekend.  Many branch level employees, particularly managers, seem to be complacent in their roles which can be very frustrating to someone who is ambitious to advance beyond a basic retail role.  Bonuses are also awarded with no consistency between business units (with managers often threatening individuals who share with others what they were paid) and no specific formula followed.  It seems this can cause confusion, if not genuine distrust between the employee and the company as a whole.  It can also result in individuals being penalised for the performance of their larger business unit despite strong personal performance.  Benefits are not commensurate with a company of this size, insurance coverage often involves low coverage amounts of higher co-pays.  Most other benefits are also taxable, so keep this in mind.  Office culture is very dry, employees are not encouraged to socialise with each other, and people are often reassigned frequently to other branches.  The company will insist employees participate in sponsored charities (United Way, Run for the Cure, etc) however employees are expected to contribute on their own, and are not compensated.

headline: Financial Services
pros: Good for immigrants starting a career in banking.
cons: Favouritism and very little chance to grow after securing entry level position.

headline: Best Place to Learn
pros: Best environment for beginner and motivated place
cons: fast pased environment and less satisfaction

headline: Don't work for them
pros: Pros can be just you can get your "banking experience" and move to the better FI.
cons: First of all the level of the employees knowledge is a very limited. I had a lot of time conference call with Financial Advisors and what surprised me is that they are selling Mutual Funds, Investments but they don't know difference between stocks and bonds? I even surprised how they passed Mutual Funds exams?! Again I am talking about Financial Advisors or FSRs overall in Canada. Secondly, how CIBC can assign person for mentoring Insurance products, where that person never have worked at Insurance Company before? The level of knowledge of CIBC employee is a very low, even Branch Manager, how you can be a manager of the branch if you don't know or even heard in your life about CFA designation? CIBC keep asking you to reach your sales target and the same time pushing clients go to the online and telephone banking?! How stupid is it, you don't have tones of new clients every day but you keep asking about sales targets. Keep calling the same clients over the phone and keep offering them the same offer which you asked 1 or 3 month ago? CIBC head office or Vise Presidents don't like to pay for your financial courses which can help you to move up and after that complaining that people don't like to stay at CIBC.

headline: FSR
pros: Great learning environment. Valuable sales lesson that stay with you for life.
cons: Micromanaging and upper level management with limited to no formal education.

headline: CIBC- The good, the bad, and the ugly
pros:
Overall, CIBC is a rewarding company to start your career at (but not to grow it). Career success here has very little to do with actual performance, driven mostly by networking and relationships built internally. 

It's important to keep in mind that Retail Banking and HQ are completely different- so you can't clump it into one review. Don't expect to start as a CSR and then move into head office even 4 years later. It's not happening.
cons:
-CIBC spends very little time and money on training and development for their employees. 
-Unless you have 5 years of experience in your career and are moving laterally into CIBC, the salary is vastly below the market. I've took a lateral move externally and am now making more than my old manager 
-Very cheap organization for basic things you would expect elsewhere, i.e sponsoring designation renewals, paying for employee recognition, employees have to pay for time out as a group 
-Too much focus on "thought leadership", but little critical thinking is actually used
-Large company focus on diversity, but little to no visible minorities in upper management 
-High level of micro managing, check ins
-Excessive amount of meetings that could have been an email

headline: Customer Service Representative - Good work experience, but branches are not what they used to be...

-Perfect student job
-Build great experience and learn a lot
cons:
-Lot of pressure to push clients towards ABMs and online platforms while still increasing sales goals
-A lot has to do with internal politics (if your boss doesn't like you, no matter how good of an employee you are, you won't get the bonus you deserve or won't have the opportunities to go up while if your boss likes you but you suck at your job, you will still get your bonus and the promotions)

Senior management looks like has no clue about the operations, or prefers to ignore it. 
Junior management reads positive thinking phrases on morning meetings to motivate the overloaded staff. Prefers to check desks cleanliness to face/solve the real problems.
Management relays on gossip to evaluate work individually.
No yearly adjustments by inflation (yes, every year you make less money).
Complaints if you get sick. 
No great career opportunities in Montreal.

headline: Unpleasant Workplace
pros:
- For a someone starting out it offers adequate health, dental, and disability benefits
- The company is at least trying to move towards a modern banking experience, although not going far enough.
- Stable hours if you get a permanent position
cons:
- Starting compensation is the lowest of the big five banks and the Caisse
- Management is generally unqualified to be in there positions.
- Management is only interested in pushing product with no regard for creating a better client experience. Everything is about sales and regardless of how valuable you are in terms of solving customer issues and and improving a client’s experience the only metric you will be judged by is how many credit cards, LOC’s, etc. you can push. Because of this, (no surprise) client retention is abysmal.
- Rather than coaching, mentoring and providing helpful insight the go-to tactics for motivating employees is bullying and indirectly threatening the possibility of being fired. 
- Product information and coaching documents are available in the labyrinth like database of information for employees, but A) it’s extremely difficult to find answers to questions, and B) The material available refers mainly to sales tactics and how to bypass customer complaints rather than addressing them. 
- There’s a huge turnover rate of people that move onto better banks out of the big five and those who have ended up staying at CIBC seem bitter and very passive aggressive. It’s understandable when you look at the type of treatment from the top but regardless it makes for a very unpleasant workplace.

They would only pay for IFIC and will not pay for CSC. even though you are required CSC to be license for IROC for imperial service if you want to advance. Limited career movement due to branch politics.  Of course if your parents work for the higher up management in CIBC, you would have advancement opportunity. headline: Very disappointing!!!!!!
pros: Free chequing account free chequing  account Free chequing account free chequing  account
cons:
I have been working as a CSR and then senior CSR for 3 years, please look at this if you wish to start a career at CIBC.
- NO INCREASE at pay, doing senior csr  job and receiving regular csr pay
- NO full time positions provided ( they just do not wish to give me full time)
- NO career advancement. I have won several quarterly awards, being nominated a few times, won award of excellence, and manager rated my performance as " unsatisfactory" 
- DISCRIMINATION. If you are from other cultures, you can move as far as FSR and that's the end of your financial career. No management opportunities given to diverse cultures. One of the staff was fired by my manager and was told " need to improve English" because she spoke with an accent. 
- LESS EDUCATED managers. Don't know if she ever had a college degree. Maybe. Know NOTHING about management.
- ONLY care about sales. No client oriented at all.
- Favouritism. Giving worst hours to me and best schedule to some employee she likes
- can't schedule own vacation, she will arrange FOR YOU!
- micro management. If you went on lunch 5 mins late, she will be super MAD.no matter how you are doing at sales (I'm always at 150%), never recognize any contribution you made.
- very negative environment make me sick 
- everything is a number game.
- relatinship worth more than skills
- education not valued AT ALL.
- most FSR are hired externally without a decent degree and knows nothing about investment before
- heavy LABOR WORK. Balancing ATM machine everyday!!!!

headline: Still has a very long way to go...
pros:
Inspired CEO has presented a compelling vision for the future of the organization
Solid corporate citizenship with generous support for volunteerism & worthy causes
Strong relationships with colleagues that turn into lasting friendships
cons:
The organization has taken several bad decisions at very senior levels over the last 15 years that have resulted in a risk-averse, CYA culture - they have a long way to go to transform the culture and the organization - the actions of many senior executives do not appear to support the required changes to achieve the CEO's vision
While trust among team members is high, trust in colleagues outside team lags significantly contributing to unhealthy power struggles / turf battles and makes collaboration very challenging 
There is a big gap between the expressed commitment to support career progression and the reality / scarcity of internal promotions and transfers
Compensation is at the lower end relative to the other domestic banks 
Very little support for conference participation

cons: Unbelieveable workload from my branch.

headline: Culture needs work...

cons: Almost too risk focused - lots of layers to go through to get things done; culture needs a lot of attention

headline: Advisory Application Developer

headline: Co-Op Analyst
pros: Very good and recommended to all. You'll enjoy your time and will learn a lot more. People will help you out. Also you can get to apply internal positions.
cons: nothing in specific to inform

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Great people and multiple opportunities to experience different aspects of banking. Work life balance.
cons: Slow to change due to size and history. Each department has a different culture and is run like an independent organization.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: They provide an excellent benefits package that includes both short term and long term coverage in event of an illness.
cons: They expect you to sell credit cards, bank accounts, mortgages, loans, etc. They also effectively cap your income. FInally they restrict your compensation to only new money brought in, not AUM.

headline: Lots of Opportunity; No Direction.
pros: CIBC will expect you to hit the ground running. They truly give you an opportunity to push yourself to learn and develop.
cons: No matter the amount of time and effort you put in, politics will always trump your career progression.

headline: qa
pros: the co-workers are great and helpful,great atmosphere
cons: Nothing much to learn in contract as the full time people are not interested to share their knowlede with contract workers

headline: think twice
pros: good co-workers, if overworked. Putting some money into long neglected facilities and premises.
cons:
Training is not this companies interest, and it is reflected in horrible retention rate (which pushes them to increase targets while you are training ironically-trainees now need to write mortgages). Some districts have loss rate of 50%+ in first year. There is NO training program for mgrs, so pray for a experienced one. Intake hires- out of group of 12 or so 3-4 will be left after 6 months.
This is the training bank. If you can survive first year of "self directed learning" you may likely be poached by other FI as CIBC does not compensate well, which also contributes to loss rate.
Note bank is eliminating front line positions and back office in drive to go online.

The loss rate is pushing inexperienced people into roles long before they are ready.

headline: Good overrall
pros: Great learning opportunities/career coaching if you follow the preset "formula"/if you get placed in a good branch then all is well/friendly atmosphere
cons: Sales pressure for both financial and customer reps/ formulaic in terms of promotions-good luck climbing the ladder if you deviate from "set in stone" path/ slight tendency to nitpick non issues

headline: Truly rewarding and highly respectable position.
pros: Excellent support from Managers, NSL- National support line/EHD- Employee help desk, District representatives such as Mutual Funds Specialist, Lending and Mortgage Specialist, Insurance Specialist etc who help you in your role and your overall success. Overall hard work, dedication and motivation with desire to succeed is recognized by management and appreciated. Employee morale in the company is very positive. Targets are achievable especially with tools provided to succeed in your role. FSR is a highly respectable and professional role. You meet really interesting people from all walks of life. Helping clients make important decisions and guiding them through a maze of financial products and services is your role. FSR in reality a Financial Planner or Financial Adviser since you deal with everything such as chequing account, loan, mortgage, mutual funds and credit cards etc. Job stability is high, pay is great and the role in the bank is not a job but a career. This is a sales role so be prepared to sell with passion and confidence because at the end of the day if you are doing what's best for the client, it's not really selling but rather advising. Job is easier when you are in a big branch as there are lot of walk ins and you can capitalize each meeting to meet your sales targets (coming from someone who's worked both in the biggest branch and smallest branch).
cons: As of 2016, the annual sales targets have gone up in terms of Bas unit sales which is mostly from opening new deposit accounts, ovedraft, credit cards etc. However at the same time CIBC is promoting Digital Migration that is any client that walks in to a branch, FSRs are expected to pretty much show them how to do everything online including opening a new account on your phone and applying for a credit card etc. Not too bad if for branch sales people including CSRs if you're in a big branch with lots of walk in but if you're in a small branch, it can make your job extremely hard. You will have to make a lot more calls in the office to get clients into the branch I'd say 2 to 3 hours daily in a small branch as opposed to 1 hour in a big branch.

headline: A good place to start your career in banking
pros: opportunities for career advancement are good, can always apply for promotion or other positions that interest you
cons: they don't have strategies to keep employees, they are underpay, people leave their jobs, turn over rate is high

headline: Heading in the right direction

headline: Credit Adjudication
pros: I think they are 5th out of the top 5 banks in Canada so they cannot go any lower.
cons: Micromanaging at its worst. No work/life balance. Horrible work culture. Poor processes. Misguided Senior Management. Unrealistic targets. Too many changes that don't create any real value for clients or employees. Treating employees poorly.

headline: Senior Financial Services Representative
pros: At least they give me a job.
cons:
-Low pay high pressure. (80% of customers I served, income are higher than mine. that make me feel sad)

-Only care about numbers. Feel like I'm just a number.

-Work in an office but feel like I'm a telemarketing representative.

-Do not support continuing education. Beside mutual fund license, anything else are declined with reason that I do not need that for my job. (Including CSC, PFP & CFP)

-No one care if you work 1 hours unpaid overtime every other day to help customer, but you are not allow to come late to work for 1 minutes. (of course if I don't care about customer, I can leave on time when the door closed)

-High turnaround, 95% of the colleagues I originally start working with are all gone. YES, 95%!!

headline: Really fair hours / competence based evaluation.

-Was allowed to define my own project and given full liberty to implement it
cons: -Having to wear a suit sometimes

headline: its good
pros: stable job with not much growth
cons: aggressive too much micro mangement

headline: Very Bad
pros: The benefits are about the only good thing if you can handle everything else.
cons: Its all about the "numbers" and never the employees.  Raises are 5 cents a year after working extremely hard. They only notice your "sales numbers" and not the back office or investigation work put in. They cut hours down because our "transaction count" is low. However they don't factor how many clients walk out because of the wait for one teller. A "transaction" may be a wire payment or changing a bank card that could take up to 15 mins per client. Extended hours but they keep cutting staff. Very stressful . They don't support people who have families and kids. This job is best suited for single people who only are interested in sales. Pay is horrible for the effort and work involved.  Bonuses are a joke. Why even bother. Cheap company. .if we want a lunch brought in or have an event together you have to pay your own way. Pretty much everything.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: CIBC creates more opportunity for career growth and advancement for young folks willing to grow their career. I feel proud to recommend CIBC to any young person with dreams of making it far in their career becase in CIBC every achievement no matter how little is celebrated. I have worked for one of the top banks in Canada before CIBC and there was almost no room for growth for young people and CIBC is awesome. Lots of new and upcoming changes that is currently creating more opportunities and new jobs. I am excited and optimistic about my career with CIBC
cons: There is a lot more pressure to sell products/services to clients. You feel the pressure of work and it is continous. So you may want to reconsider it if you don't like constant pressure and emails that will push you to the extreme. Once you get a hang of the job depending on your job family it is easier to adapt.

headline: Director
pros:
Good people. Great team. 
Amazing quality of work and never a dull moment. 
Depending on the group you're with, career advancement can be good.
Benefits are decent, as is the pay.
CIBC is a good social citizen and genuinely cares about the community.
cons:
Unrealistic pressure to deliver, and even when you do, only the negative is seen. Work life balance is severely compromised and has been in a downward spiral for over a year now. Do more with the same people, where the reward for good work, is more work and tighter timelines. 

Lack of trust between groups, and some serious political grand standing may result in poisoning the culture and dynamic which has led to so many successes over the years.

Harassment of customers by outbound calling. 
Terrible compensation when you overachieve your goals with little to no recognition.

Take home [ay lower as you subsidize your own benefits -- investment program is sub-contracted and very weak -- just do it on your own. headline: Financial Service Rep
pros: Reliable income, meet different people. Learn various lending tools and interest generating vehicles.  Good entry level into the financial world.  Brand recognition.
cons: Unrealistic sales goals, tenured employees with established client base have same targets as new empployees.  Employees not promoted or recognized based on excellent customer service recognition is based on managed money who can sell more.  Sketchy management encouraging employees to put clients in the wrong type of investment to help branch with revenue.  Pay is the lowest out of all retail banks.  Prospective calls to clients have already been harassed by telephone banking and do not want to have a conversation.  The laying off of employees who service clients creating advisors to do sales and servicing.,  Charging full service fees for clients but telling them to do everything online or via mobile.  Financial Service Representatitves are expected to attract clients for mortgages but are not allowed to even give competitive rates because that decreases revenue.  Unesecured lending is almost impossiblly unattractive for new clients because rates are ridiculously high since they have no products with CIBC to begin with.

headline: Things could be better
pros: Victor Dodig's vision is promising.  I hope it takes root.  He is the one positive element of the senior leadership team.
cons: Feel like a chicken in my tiny cubicle, just driven to lay eggs and be disposed off during the next round of layoffs, when I am replaced by a younger chicken.  Seriously, within the Capital Markets Technology area management looks at staff as disposable.  You get your pizza on employee appreciation day and that is about it.  There is no appreciation, just the threat of dismissal if you do not work harder.  When you are burned out, you are replaced.  This commentary is not representative of the entire organization.  There are great departments to work for.  Stay away from CMT while Richard Jardim and his crew run the show.

headline: mortgage processing offcIer

headline: Felt like I was part of a cattle call hiring, did textbook-style training then abandoned to reach high sales goals.
pros: It's an international company. There are various jobs available for you to move within the org. There are many branches within the country.

headline: Very positive - good culture.  Excited by the direction that our CEO is taking our Bank
pros: A culture of continuous improvement and doing what's right for the client.  Feels good to work at a top tier financial institution who gives back to the community and cares about its clients.
cons: Compared to other sectors it is sometimes challenging to get things done.  Not a flat organization - many levels of management.

headline: Financial Service Representative
pros: Decent salary, learn values such as trust, teamwork and accountability

headline: Non cooperative, harassing, bureaucratic and red-taped work place
pros: Its been an hour, cannot think of  a single one!
cons:
Have been an  application developer for more than 6 years, and I have worked for lot of different clients but this is by far the worst  red-taped work place i have worked at. Employees are never appreciated for the work that gets the company moving but are actually pushed down. Its a very micro-managed environment where a non technical manager leads a team of developers. HAHA

They talk as a place where employees are heard and promoted to enhance their careers ;" IN YOUR DREAMS."

headline: Terrible experience
pros:
Banking benefits
Good insurance coverage
Extensive training
Great location
cons:
Evening and weekend shifts
Every aspect of your work is examined and has a goal for you to reach (duration of calls, sales, retention of clients...)
No freedom to handle cases, everything is codified
Management has absolutely no trust in its empoyees
Feeling like a number, not even a human being, let alone an employee or part of a team

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Great Pay , Flexible Hours, Vacation Pay, Health Insurance, Good Management , Great opportunities for advancement.
cons: Big Emphasis on Sale,  Although training is long and detailed it focuses on the wrong things,  Reward Staff Members on a daily basis not just when they get someone in the office.

headline: Overall an "ok" experience

headline: Job at HQ- Review
pros:
- Work/life balance is fair
- Colleagues are exceptionally talented folks who become friends
- Work environment is top notch- latest technology, bright boardrooms etc
cons:
- Little encouragement or support for professional growth 
- Management across the board seems to be extremely concerned with their personal image rather than the employees they are supposed to be managing
- The salary is fair, but not exceptional 
- CIBC as a whole is a very top-down organization. Suggestions from the more junior employees are rarely taken seriously, and when they are, senior management / executives tend to take credit for them
 - CIBC embodies a hierarchical structure- there are way too many layers of management.

headline: toxic and brutal
pros: you do get paid.  there are some good people who work there.
cons: too long to list.  company just doesn't care about people.  under trained, under educated but highly motivated people make their way up in this company, and numbers and 'business results' are the only drivers. the result is poor management at best, bullying and demeaning at worst. most people inside are unhappy and looking for a way out.  turn over in my region was shockingly high. terrible employer.

headline: check three times, sign once... with lots of care !
pros: if you need a job, you may get this one. absolutely nothing to brag about.... !
cons: Define how competent your manager is in this environment BEFORE you sign !!! Is really hard to find a bunch of executives so weak at doing their job in any other corporations. Also be prepared to be thrown under the bus multiple times... especially if you really try doing your job.... and not your manager job (very important). After you work here you may believe that your manager is completely incapable in finding another job ...

headline: Senior Director, Program Management

headline: A great place to work.

headline: It's all about numbers....

cons: One has to bring business where ever he/she can. They expect you bring mortgage, investment from outside and set an unrealistic target for new comers which is almost impossible to achiever. If you are a direct fire from outside do not expect to get time to learn about their system software.

headline: Work Environment
pros:
Good Benefits, No Account Fees/month for employees, 50% off on most of the services, lower mortgage rates, good investment offers for investing in shares. 
Best department to work is Finance Technology amazing people and lots to learn.
cons: People are good in few of the departments. Retail and Business banking testing team is welcoming but, w'll talk at your back and few team mates will try to pull you down. Not a professional environment.

headline: Financial services representative II
pros: Great benefits and employee banking offers, friendly co-workers and very understanding managers and dvps. Very comprehensive training programs.
cons: Too much pressure to meet the sales targets.  The bank apparently claims that they have changed their focus from being sales oriented to client centric but there are no such practise in place to exhibit that. Quite stressful and alot of pressure with little support.little bit behind in terms of tech advancement

headline: Hard to advance

cons: Difficult to advance-management will often hold you back in favour of those they like more. headline: Financial Services Representative

headline: Manage portfolio of clients
pros: Good software for financial planning. FPC support. Some managers are good. Flexibility with product options that can be offered to clients.
cons: Extremely complicated compensation plan. No matter what results are, if don't sell certain products or have a certain mix of products, can miss out on significant income. Seems like some portfolios won't generate income regardless of sales too many clients on portfolios.

headline: Intern

headline: Fast-paced, challenging work.
pros: I was on the credit risk team for front office, and sat on the trading floor. The work environment is amazing: fast-paced, loud, collaborative. You get to work with people that are very smart and good at what they do, many of whom have years of experience and a deep understanding of their jobs. The work was diverse, with new month-long projects appearing regularly, interspersed with regular requests for calculations or information with a 5-minute turnaround.
cons: As one might expect: eventually you ask yourself what you're really contributing to the world. Banks do provide a necessary service to the business world, and capital markets are no different, but there's a difference between challenging and interesting work, and work you're passionate about.

headline: A nice atmosphere!
pros:
I work in an amazing team,we support each other,everybody is friendly and helpful.
I am glad I had the opportunity to experience this kind of atmosphere.
cons: There are almost no downsides,very minor aspects considering the condition of the office,but it doesn't affect in any way my job.

headline: Poor Training
pros: Recruitment Process was amazing, outlined everything that was expected, times lines etc. Interview with manager went well, vague on the specifics but I was new to banking so I was ensured that there was a very strong extensive training program in place.  Part time min 15 hours a week was my offer.
cons: Entered first day not knowing what to expect..spent entire day watching modules with no interaction with others...(bank short staffed) given the modules required to be completed with in 1st 60 days...told I would work every day until they were done...completed them (each module suggests you watch the action being performed...or work with the teller so it makes sense). 20 days later I have a cash & being told I that I have completed the required training and am still making mistakes...even after asking for my mistakes to be pointed out to me they would and could not...I offered to retrain in certain areas where they thought I was weak or have someone watch me "in a perfect world that would be great"  and they said I should know it by know...bwahahahaha

headline:
Financial Services Representative 
Telephone Banking/ OLB Support 

Challenging, but it's hard to knock the pros
pros:
Great benefits, 3 week vacation in the first year, 38k to start, transit friendly location, 6 month paid training. Instructors are really friendly and try to make it as easy as possible if you come from a non banking background. 
Free banking and great employee rates. 
Career growth within the bank eventually, depending on what you're looking for. 
If you meet sales targets for 6 months (2 quarters) you get a 2k permanent raise, followed by another 2k raise if you meet for a second 6 months. So 42k plus end year bonus. Some guys make like 60k gross but they sell like crazy.  

To be honest I never finished college and I feel I have the potential for a long career if I play my cards right. There are days when I loathe the job however if you can stick it out there is potential for a long and well paid career. To make 42k without schooling and without breaking your back by doing physical labor, there are deff worst jobs out there to be had. It is not perfect but it could be a lot worse and a lot less pay and I Have been there so I am thankful for what I have.
cons:
Some clients that call in are just really awful people, a lot of stress if not meeting targets, you will prob work afternoons for 2 plus years (f you last that long) because shift bids are based on seniority. 
Targets have been adjusted to be more manageable but it is stressful quarter after quarter to meet them and some days you want to just stand up and quit. But then you think about the pros I mentioned above and you keep going. 

It is deff not for everyone and I almost gave up a few times, but I have an really great team leader who helped me with my sales so it's not as bad anymore. Half of the 14 or so people that we started training with have quit or got fired, but a few also have moved on to better positions within the bank.

headline: Financial Service Representatiev
pros: no pros with working at this place.  This place pays the least out of the top 5 banks and expects the most.
cons:
They advertised the job as 9-5 but gives you ridiculous targets that can clearly not be met with just 8 hours.  In order to meet their targets, you have to stay much longer in order to fulfill your requirements.  The more appropriate title for the Financial Service Representative position is telemarketer.  They expect their FSRs to make 35 live contact calls weekly and left messages, no pick ups, do not count.  They judge you on a system where anything below 50% counts as zero to make you feel worse than you already do.  CIBC prides themselves on mobile and telephone banking when those are not real advantages.  Simply put, expect a high stress environment sent from the top down with pay that does not justify the work.  You would notice that the average tenor of a CIBC bank employee is 1 year and very rarely would you encounter representatives that are properly trained to do investments or mortgages.  Their training program gives you the very basic theories of financial planning as it is a entry level retail job but throws you out to the front lines without any real hands on experience.

They've self-proclaimed themselves to being a client-centric bank when they haven't made any changes to being that.  They're a very heavily product focused company that has a target system that may not necessarily work out in the best interest of clients when their workers are trying to meet their BAS (units measured for sales)

headline: If you are looking for bank job go somewhere else
pros: A lot of opportunity to move up because there are tons of people leaving this organization. The turn over is crazy. The executives are trying to turn around the bank so there are hopes but they are not going too deep about the root causes. There are  no team work between branch, imperial service, wood Gundy and credit card center and commercial banking. people just want sales target to be done. Nobody care about service. No matter how good service you do, you will get treat like you are useless if you can't sell. Only solid salesperson get to stay. Mangers are very roughy to bad salesperson to make them quit. They try to not letting the good salesperson move up. Average performance are stuck. Everybody just thinking of getting a job in other bank as exit strategy. No authority to staff. Everything is not allowed. A lot of hierarchies. System is so old fashion like in the 40s. If you refer business to your partner you will get absolutely nothing nobody is helping each other. Everybody work together are competitors. There is no partner within the bank. Pay is well below market avenger and that's why people are leaving after training. Only wild animal can survive and excel. If you work in this bank and excel you have all the ability to be successful in anywhere any organization. And that's the pros!!
cons: The executives are too conservative. The hierarchies are too strong. The performance scorecard between channels are competitor more then team. Training is good but the pay is low; everybody get trained and moved on to other bank for higher pay. Turn over is crazy. No authority to staff. Not very competitive. Leaders only looks for sales numbers. And leadership means how to get people work for no pay. The bonus is just a joke. No incentive to work hard as financial service rep or even senior. THe compensation for imperial service advisor keep getting cut down year after years. Advisors are all bringing their client and go to other FI. Leave the dust to CIBC. Managers and executives are getting fat pay and not helping. Keep bringing new technology but not focus on how to link the branch core, imperial service and wood Gundy together as team. Keep spending stupid money on break away and get branch staff work like tel banking call center keep making outbound call to disturb clients. And get units and use the fact to judge outbound call works. And it actually do not work. And really low staff satisfaction. And below average pay.

headline: Top Performers bad behaviour is turned a blind eye - at every level.
pros:
Great employee banking benefits
Overall good working environment
Excellent extra perks, like the workperks site, VIP metropass discount, gym memberships
Benefits are comparable to bank peers
cons: If you're a top performer, especially a people leader, expect to get away with murder. CIBC, like any company, loves people who are high performers. But they love them at the expense of others. I've worked with and under people who lie, cheat and steal, and the company says nothing because they meet or exceed their sales targets. Those of us who do well or just a little bit under are treated poorly, bullied and made to feel like less valued employees. I struggled as a people leader under my manager because the individual sabotaged my role at every turn with the staff - and rated me poorly as I attempted to turn around a compliance poor branch. Escalations to senior management was met with disagreement with my complaint, and I was told to suck it up, and find a different job. I took a demotion to get away from the toxic environment. After nearly 15 years of dedicated service I quit for a better company.

Management sucks, they only care about sales results and have no respect for work life balance

headline: FSR Tile should be changed to Telemarketer or Sales Associate
pros:
Decent Training on retail banking fundamentals
Free Employee Banking 
Good on resume for future career opportunities OUTSIDE CIBC
cons:
Lots of CONS, I don't even know where to start: This is the worse job I've had in my entire life! 
- Extremely low pay (35K) considering the amount of hours put in, and even after obtaining IFIC and successfully going through FSRDP, my requests for a salary review were repeatedly ignored, despite consistently meeting targets. 
-They expect you to kick butt right after training and put you on the  same target scale as older employees.
-If you work under a Branch Manager who doesn't like you, you're screwed, as it was in my case. She openly harassed, bullied and intimidated me. Brushed aside all personal requests whatsoever. It was all about SALES SALES SALES. Some very arrogant Branch Managers and even some FA's who were very reluctant to assist. 
-We were MICRO-MANAGED like kids in high school really. Constantly checking on FSR'S to see where they were with targets. Monitored you pretty much every second. 
-Advancement Opportunities are hard to come by. Be prepared to stick around for quite a while if you want to move up the ladder. A branch manager flat out told me She would NEVER recommend me for any higher roles 'at this point in my career' When I needed assistance, she would ask me to call the employee help desk. 
-If you suck at sales, this is the wrong job for you. Majority of your day will be spent Calling existing clients to up-sell them stuff, majority of which get extremely pissed/annoyed when they get these calls. 
-The Targets are unrealistically high and keep going up every year. It is virtually impossible to meet all those targets with the amount of time allotted, and they will NOT pay for any over time whatsoever. Zero work-life balance. 
-Zero Bonus if your manager hates you. Your life and career advancement at CIBC pretty much lies in the hands of your direct manager. Even when transferring branches to the same FSR role. 
-Lots of conflicting feedback from various levels of management (Branch manager, District manager, and DVP) 
One tells you one thing, another says some other thing. Lots of useless 'sales' meetings to attend daily when focus should be on Customer service.

headline: Unnecessarily difficult place to work. Branch level.
pros: Many nice people at work but can be very clique-y.  Lots of job experience.  Lots of coaching.
cons: Coaching to the point of being annoying.  Emphasis on sales, sales, sales. Selling to people who can't afford the products is encouraged. Boring contests that don't pay out. When people win the big across-Canada contests they have to pay a ton of taxes on the prize.  Management can be secretive and sneaky  There is no privacy for you  if  you do any banking there,...they talk amongst themselves about your transactions. Lots of high-school drama and gossip. Some places managed better than others.  I worked at 2 branches....the management at one of them was phony, mean, and nasty, and the other  was fantastic, kind, and well-liked.  The payscale compared to other banks is the  lowest.
