headline: Good Start for a Career in Banking
pros: Very diverse workplace, great to meet people from different cultures,busy work environment,great benefits but compensation could be better.
cons: sales targets are always the basis of promotion and recognition, complicated company policies and office procedures.

headline: A good place
pros:
Smart management team that has deep experience in digital marketing and technology.
Only place I have worked in which management actively encourages employees to try out different jobs and work in different departments.
Very smart people who are, naturally, competitive. But that competitiveness doesn't get in the way of what has become a close-knit family.
Comes from classic tech/advertising start-up roots and still maintains much of that feel within its offices
cons:
Only place I have worked in which management actively encourages employees to try out different jobs and work in different departments.
Very smart people who are, naturally, competitive.

headline: Stressful work environment, robbery risk.
pros: Good benefits for staff: free service charges and discounted rates on loans and mortgages.
cons: Low pay, short breaks, stressful environment.  Constantly on your back to sell more...even when the client doesn't need a product you are expected to sell something.

headline: Not A Place for A Great Career
pros: Nothing but pay and downtown location.
cons: Management does not care about employees' career path. Old boys club.

headline: overworked
pros: opportunity to move up in the company
cons: unnessesary constant stress from management

headline: Product Manager
pros: Great people, atmosphere, hours. I was able to have a work-life balance and worked with a great team of people.
cons: Not many movement opportunities. I found coming in a jr. I was not able to move around teams very easily, with little help to do so

headline: Cibc
pros: Great I'd you work in a friendly branch
cons: Bad communication between departments, system sucks

headline: Demotivating place to work
pros: The only decent thing about working here is that you never take your work home with you. Punch in and punch out.
cons:
Adhering to a strict schedule, especially if you're taking inbound calls.
The compensation is paltry at best. Most people here can't make ends meat on their own income. The practice of low pay leads to employee resentment which, in turn, breeds an undesirable culture.
There is a severe lack of career opportunities. Internally, you can either apply to be a supervisor (which is a dead-end position in and of itself) or you can apply to be an analyst with technology or another supporting department. Moving up or laterally outside of the line of business is harder than it should be for competent and productive employees.

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: Lots of turnover so opportunity to advance
cons: Not compensated enough for work required

headline: After two years, it's been enough.
pros:
- salary (debatable for some)
- bonus and raises scheme - though this is debatable as so much relies on management, but a lot is in your control
- benefits
- steadiness
- diversity... but see below
cons:
- diversity. It could be better. For minorities, females, handicapped especially those that want to move up...
- upward mobility. This is tough as the general corporate structure is a pyramid, so there's only so far people can go.
- leadership. In my department, we have a new VP (about a  year). Wonderful person to work with, but no vision.
- general management. And without going into incendiary details, mostly the reason why i'm leaving. Lack of autonomy, micromanagement, comes off hypocritical (though I don't think they mean to be)

headline: Genuinely care. Not all departments created equal
pros: Good culture with a renewed focus on continuous improvements and work life balance. Depending on department, lots of support and opportunity for growth and promotion.
cons: Pay might not match other FIs, but it's balanced by a group of good people. Work load can get hectic at times, but I suspect that's the case everywhere based on fiscal expectations.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Great people, good environment. Good pay
cons: Lack of continuous training, and lack of support from management

headline: Ideal Working Environment
pros: One of the biggets financial institution in Canada
cons: Heavy workload at times due to current projects.

headline: Pressured beyond your capacity...
pros: Bank account discounts and fees are waived, employee credit card lower rates and other bank product has lower rates for employees.
cons:
sales goals and targets are unrealistically high!
terrible management.
favouritism with staff.
Only a portion of medical benefits are paid.
Sales, sales, sales!

headline: Poor work and balance lifestyle, no programs
pros: Large organization where you can move around for experience.
cons: Internal senior promotions are very difficult to achieve. CIBC likes to hire outside for senior management and executive levels.

headline: Great company
pros: Great place to work, lots of opportunities to grow, open job posting system, good salary and perks, access to senior management.
cons: Huge workplace, people can get lost in the complex infrastructure if one is not clear about his career goals, takes time to understand relationships between groups.

headline: Big Mistake
pros: Benefits Plan.  Nice kitchen.  Wide open spacious.  Beautiful view of Halifax Harbor from lunch room.
cons: Horribly managed.  Delving into personal feelings, personal life.  Young unknowable management.  Very poor customer service.  Leaving customers on hold for coaching issues.

headline: Lots of opportunity
pros: Large organization with the opportunity to gain experience across many lines of business.
cons: Little work and life balance.

headline: Excellent Starting Point
pros: Excellent support while learning the industry
cons: Considerable pay difference for same role in other bank

headline: Great opportunity. Poor management. Customer Service Representative.
pros: My coworkers are great people. The client relationships I've built in the 2 years I've worked at CIBC are amazing. Excellent hours and stability.
cons: Unfortunately young kids are hired into roles they are not ready for. It's a big gap for CIBC. Management is not very understanding when it comes to your personal life either. If you communicate to your superior that you, in fact, do not want to absorb  responsibilities of another role (that you will not properly be compensated for) guess what?  It will be pushed on you. Without training. And with 5 people telling you 5 different ways of doing said role.

headline: work hard but pay low
pros: good work environment in downtown
cons: stressful work load, pay lower compared with other banks

headline: its a good place to work especially for anew comer in Canada
pros: diversity. good benefits, multiculturalism, good ambience
cons: not very open for growing to the next level

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Company values, Office culture, team members, quality of work
cons: multiple process groups, work-life balance

headline: Life changing
pros: Stability - professional - our senior leadership has really been inspiring as of late - great vision and focus on future state
cons: at times stoic and slow to change

headline: FSR II
pros: Good office culture, Fantastic training program
cons: no work life balance, Your growth will lot depend upon your manager

headline: Like most large size enterprises in Canada - stable and moving slowly.
pros: Good work-life balance and training opportunities.
cons: It is not a dynamic environment where enhancements are made easy.

headline: Good for newer employees or those with lots of credentials.
pros: Good banking benefits.  Also good brand name recognition with valuable sub-brands (e.g. Wood Gundy).  Overall decent compensation although you will often be told you are expensive.
cons: Big push to eliminate many of the experienced/expensive employees from the support areas and replace them with less experienced/expensive generalists.

headline: FSR II Review
pros: Good Benefits and possible opportunity to move up
cons: targets are not adjusted to area

headline: Excellent financial systems and clear guidelines
pros: Good pay at market rate, work life balance. Systematic reporting tools, good report planning. Will not just focus on english presentation but rather on the material (meat) of the reports.
cons:
Staff relationship not good, no staff gathering, very separate but yet no gossiping (which is good)
One bad thing is the corporate title is a lot higher than the title in your reference letter (reference check), such as a Senior Finance Manager title used everyday but when you left, they reported you as a Senior Financial Analyst. So your current employer may think you lied about your title in the resume.

headline: Good company with lots of opportunity in sales and leadership roles
pros: Lots of opportunity for promotion if you can achieve aggressive targets/expectations. They offer training programs for certain roles.
cons: The company believes in micromanagement, but calls it supportive leadership. Very high expectations, especially with support roles being eliminated over time. Work,life balance is very challenging, especially in leadership roles.  Bonus structure complicated and hard to predict.

headline: They pay you
pros:
they pay you
give you vacation
cons:
no right tool for the work
work with no growth
i don't like the management here

headline: good
pros: good working environmental, nice locations
cons: it takes lots of time to start working

headline: Good work culture
pros: Manager don't put extra pressure and do not micro manage your activities
cons: Perks and growth opportunities at some places are challenge

headline: As a Learning developer, my main responsibility is to design and develop training modules for HRCs.
pros: Encouraging work atmosphere and freedom.
cons: Old versions of software and IT service requests take too long to be processed.

headline: A great first job post grad
pros: Employee banking perks, commercial banking training program, room for growth
cons: Its easy to get overwhelmed by processes and procedures.. especially after being hired in from a smaller business. Computer systems are archaic to say the least. Windows XP and Office 2013 lol

headline: CIBC employee
pros: Great career development plan. Great people to work with.
cons: The sales target are high

headline: Great working environment
pros: Good office culture. Lots of activities.
cons: Cant think of any cons

headline: FSR
pros: Good people, nice schedule. The training is really good and you can feel that the management care about it.
cons: High pressure, bad software (compass the new software is new and it show) and sadly and most importantly : low salary for fsr2. However it you're able to achieve your goal (hello breakaway) you can be promote pretty fast.

headline: Anonymous
pros: friendly staff to work with, co-operative within your own team. good clients, some good senior leaders, good benefits and vacation.
cons: Sales leaders who just follow orders - no human element of actually leading a team. Overly micro-managed on the sales people, creates tension and frustrations amongst all staff.  Always reducing expenses at the lowest level of the Bank- the sales force. should all have one on one support- given the ridiculous sales targets. Outdated systems and cumbersome paper involved in the sales cycle. If you what people to sell and give advice- take away the behind the scenes paper, approval, etc and give them support- so they can continue to produce more. Mgmt attempts to create one team- however each division has its own ridiculous targets- hence continual in-fighting for clients between segments. Clients never really in the right offer. NEW LEADERSHIP - SHOULD TAKE NOTE 100% - to really create One Bank approach stop penalizing staff when a client goes to another segment as it creates frustrations for all staff, including mgrs.  Also no room for advancement unless you have a mentor, friend you know, it is not what you know but who you know . Wrong people promoted for management with no people management skills nor leadership skills - since no real succession in moving upwards.

headline: great contract work
pros: flexible hours that recognize good work
cons: there is tooooo much bureaucracy

headline: Account Manager
pros: Its a good place to meet people and gain experience.  The benefits are good the pay is below some other FI's for the similar position. The employees are generally good to work with.
cons: Its a good place to start out but then you should jump to a more stable bank in terms of terminations.  They over hire and let go of people, risk department is a joke, clients are nothing but numbers are the employees. The management is sub-par and get promoted due to the fact that the capable people leave to other banks and the left over moves up.  Poor senior management in leadership direction.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros:
Great way to gain sales experience
Learn how to do many types of transactions
Good team environment
cons:
Model is built too much around achieving sales
Progress is very slow. If you hold a university degree they wouldn't even consider you for a role more related to your skills unless you slowly work your way through the company (csr->fsr... Etc). Cannot go from a csr to anything else.

headline: Outbound Calls To the Limits
pros: Strongest Bank in North America and one of the best in the world.
cons: Open late and even weekends. Open 7 days a week.

headline: You're a number
pros: Colleagues, good experience, decent pay as a student, lots of possible job opportunities
cons: This company treats you like a number, not a person. Their HR policies and HR call line are horrible. They don't go beyond giving you the bare bones, they don't care and when you finally go to a company that cares, you see it. Not surprised about the overtime lawsuit. It was a matter of time before that happened. I got cheated outed of overtime for years.

headline: very turbulant in some branches
pros: if you are af avoruite of the boss yr benifit, growth compensation all are good but if not you are doomed...
cons: if you do not have a mentor/godfather dont. survival  and upward career path can be tough better thn not workig

headline: Decent
pros: Decent work life balance. Being an FI the pay is very good although I may be able to go across st for more. Time off is decent.
cons: Politics there is sooo much! Work/life varies greatly.

headline: Work hard, decent pay
pros: Decent pay, decent employees, enjoy the espp
cons: Limited opprotunities, has fallen in to the trap of making major missteps every few years.  Benefits are not great

headline: Friendly environment and good management.
pros: Friendly staff, great company culture, plenty of staff events (kept good morale).
cons: Waves of busywork and nothing to do.

headline: Regional Sales Manager
pros: Great opportunities to take on more responsibility in a growing line of buiness.
cons: Workload can be heavy at times.  There is alot of hours to cover in a business that is becoming more like 24 hours a day 7 days a week.

headline: Good place to start working at the bank.
pros: Gaining  customer service experience.
cons: Most CIBC branches don't have chairs for CSRs. You have to stand and work on your feet all day.  I believe Cibc should have chairs for CSRs like all other banks.

headline: A Really bad place to work
pros: Good career opportunities, decent compensation
cons: Terrible corporate culture, really bad work atmosphere in a lot of departments resulting in high employee turnover.

headline: eChannels - the only place to be at CIBC
pros: New VP at eChannels hope to bring new positive change.  Open door policy is promoted, decent hours but work load is still heavy.  Location is very central (Dundas Street, Atrium on Bay).  Overall, fun culture, people are generally supportive and want to do a good job.  Compensation is regularly reviewed and adjusted.  We are competitive (versus previous years).  Pushing for innovation.
cons: Other parts of CIBC are not nearly as nice as eChannels.  Very old fashioned banking mentality.  Does not supprt work from home as part of their culture.

headline: IT CIBC
pros: Not a Heavy Workload, Not difficult job
cons: Unorganized Management, Lacking in Leadership

headline: Wish I could have stayed there longer
pros: The team work was great
cons: Lots of work and at times it impacts the productivity

headline: Excellent Employer
pros: With best in the industry salary. Excellent work atmosphere, there are hardly many employers stands near CIBC.. World class and open to multicultural...
cons: Equal targets for new and old employees. Same task every time..

headline: GOOD AND BAD
pros: working place fairness is secured, senior management is always there for listening anyone's complaints. Lots of chances to learn with senior management's encouragement.
cons: can't learn too many new front-edge technologies due to concerns of stability/security of in-house developed applications

headline: BAD
pros: exposure to personal banking. good dental and medical benefits.
cons: poor management for frontline FSRs. Poor internal systems. Lots of sales pressure and stress to meet targets with no commissions.

pros: This is a stable job with little volatility. The workload is predictable and requires little background in the field. Only basic project management knowledge is required. It is all very simple to understand. There is considerable work-life balance and the compensation is good.
cons: It can be a very boring job with the same things over and over again. It feels very administrative and secretarial. There is very little engagement and it tends to be working with the same people in every project. Others on the team with a similar job work on different projects and it is all very siloed with very little interactions.

headline: BA
pros: good place to work at
cons: work life balance is not great

headline: Great place to work
pros: Hard work recognition, positive culture, great managers, opportunities to apply for another position and support to get there.
cons: Sales pressure, outdated technology platform, complex infrastructure, hard to bring changes that could improve working process and indeed client's satisfaction.

headline: Great stepping stone
pros: Strong transaction experience, good working relationship with colleagues
cons: Hours are incredibly demanding and compensation is behind the street

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Dynamic environment wit ample opportunity to utilize skills
cons: Still some elements of the old school

headline: Old process hampers productivity
pros: Work perks, Work life balance, management open to suggestions, opportunity to move into other departments.
cons: OK compensation, slow pace of work, lots of process in place, limited exposure to new technologies.

headline: Great place to work and grow
pros:
Great work environment, the staff and colleagues allow you to excel and exceed in your position and career.
There are plenty of other opportunities within CIBC, so even if you start out in one department you may not end up there.
cons: Salary is a little lower than some of the other major banks in Canada

headline: Good starting job, great motivation to find something better.
pros: Training was payed and started at a very basic level in order to help those with no financial background.
cons: Treated like children, even with impecable work ethic, very dependant on Manager  Training even treated us like jr high students.  Felt like no matter how hard I worked, or how quickly I rose to the top of sales, i was asked daily if I was "commited" to making phone calls.  Was told to turn away walk-in clients that were hoping to set up accounts in order to call existing clients and up-sell them.

headline: dont' rate 0 star, have enough good management
pros:
you have a job in big 5
standard bank package
cons:
for any team
very motivated-subordinate takes blame
stable company- no growth, 
good team work- you help others, but other don't help you.

for specific team
many opportunity-high turnover
good management skill - management takes your credit, but you are the one do all the work
recognize you by giving out garbage

headline: Real big workload, slow workers, pay can be preferential for brown nosers, and lastly favoritism.
pros: 9-5 job. Great benefits. Employee profit sharing program, bonus's at year's end. Customer's are always so great. Feels good to dress up everyday and show off at work. The only way I'll refer people is the scouting bonus they give... Every employee I know that works there say they feel over worked and under appriaciated.
cons: There can be snobby, stuck up woman. Bullies that the boss likes. Very judgemental, had a district manager that said an indian should either pick one indian or cowboy because he was wearing a cowboy hat and boots. If you make a complaint your scared to get fired.

headline: Very poor management
pros: If you work hard you can go up fast, but you have to be very hypocrite and always smile even when something isn't right.
cons: There is a lot of favouritism and directors come and go. Employees don't work there for long because if a teller doesn't make her/his references (sales) they're treated badly without any coaching available

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good work-life balance. Work from home program. Management encourages career advancement. Good training
cons: Benefits so so, compared with the likes Blackberry, HP, etc

headline: CIBC Asset Management
pros: stable bank, job is secure but promotion difficult
cons: too big lost in office structure

headline: Beware
pros: Benefits and close to transportation.
cons: They preach accountability but senior management avoids accountability at all costs.

headline: CIBC great learning experience but to much politics and the pay isnt great.
pros: You do learn alot, depending on the department the training is amazing or non existent, Large company alot of different departments to move too.
cons: Low pay compared to the other big 5 banks of course politics depending on which department your in.

headline: CSR
pros: Coworkers and clients. Assistant Branch Managers were great for the CSR's.
cons: Horrible experience with branch manager. Favouritism was blatant. High pressure sales and numbers to meet. Not necessarily what was best for the clients.

headline: Great company to work with
pros:
- Structured work processes
- Friendly people
- Great time-off policies
- encourage to take courses to improve knowledge
- good compensation and benefit package
- Work Life Balance
cons: I personally didn't come across any cons except that there is an extreme requirement to the dedication of your time to work and socializing with teams.  Sometimes if you have a lot of responsibilities, there is no time to socialize.

headline: Was not a pleasant work atmosphere
pros: Experience with a great company. Good benefits.
cons: Stuffy work environment and sub par training

headline: high pressure sales
pros: decent hours and some nice coworkers
cons: extremely LOW compensation, especially considering expectations for targets

headline: Terrible
pros: Helping clients was a good feeling
cons: Even at the financial advisor level you might just as well work in a call center 80% of your time is dedicated to annoying your existing clients with unsolicited cold calls to sell to them or book an appointment to sell to them.

headline: Reviiew
pros: Good management structure overall at the top
cons: not enough career development work

headline: great
pros: good atmosphere and friendly colleagues
cons: everything is dealt with centrally

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Innovative, community focused, support of career development
cons: Nothing to add here, thanks

headline: Be prepared to "donate" many "volunteer hours" in the branch
pros:
loved working with the public, training new staff. Many excellent training programs
Vank does tend to promote from within
cons:
very agressive targets, reach target then it's increased
expectation of too many "volunteer hours"
favouritism in staffing and rewards very obvious

headline: New blood required
pros: Work life balance was great at CIBC, and if you are fortunate enough to be in a pocket with a great people manager it's a great experience.
cons: Your people manager defines your experience with CIBC, with the number of re-organizations it's likely you'll end up with a less than competent "lifer" at one point or another.  The people who have been there for longer than twenty years actively engage in job protection, discrediting new employees and generally display unsavoury behaviours.

headline: Learned a lot, but some major structural problems, as evidenced by the incredibly high turnover.
pros: Leading Canadian institution, with a robust product offering
cons: No one liked CIBC, and although there was a lit if product, none were particularly compelling.

headline: Overall a decent place to work at
pros: Good culture and nice people to work with
cons: Lower salary compared to similar institutions

headline: Experience
pros: Great team work at CIBC
cons: salary could be better as the work load could be a lot some times

headline: Excellence co-op experience.
pros:
Excellent positive work environment.
Great learning experience.
Good balance between work and life during co-op term.
cons: Large corporation makes it difficult to get personal attention sometimes.

headline: Excellent, great benefits.
pros: The training on site was great and the pay was excellent!
cons: Long hours and it takes a while to get a promotion.

headline: Very poor experience
pros: The clients were fantastic and co workers.
cons: Managers are awful, they need to be MUCH more careful with who they are putting in charge..... Verbal and sexual harassment in my experience. Very unorganized scheduling and lack of support. All they care about is sales and targets.

headline: My experience was fairly decent.
pros: Large company with many possibilities for lateral movement within the firm. Operations in many parts of Canada so relocation is possible.  Good benefits.
cons: Training in certain parts of the firm are inadequate.  Information silos exist between separate groups within the firm.  Firm did not seem as client focused as other banks.

headline: Long hours, good colleagues
pros: Enjoyed interaction with clients, fast paced work environment
cons: This position required standing at the job for the duration of the day.

headline: Sedentary
pros: Great employee support system, lots of opportunities to grow within company, strong focus on enhancing customer service
cons: Poor training, no assistance with career development, below average salary, unfair work/life balance

headline: Good
pros: A very friendly environment. Liked working here.
cons: The working hours are late so difficult to maintain work family balance.

headline: Great learning experience.
pros: Offers opportunities to grow
cons: The branch manager is not professional enough

pros: the job was decent and fun to meet people
cons: when it got busy, it was lots of work

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: CIBC has a great environment, and motivates its employees tremendously in effective ways such as gift cards, concert/event tickets and cash bonuses.  The company also helps you grow within the company by providing you with tools in order to succeed.
cons: The hours 3pm-11pm, were a little rough, but okay

headline: Dated systems, illogical procedures that incovinience clients rather than helping them
pros: Good benefits, employee shares, free employee bank accounts
cons: Staff at the branch level are treated poorly, improper training methodologies, some of the bank managers are themselves not aware of changing technology (i actually helped my own assistant branch manager set up online banking because she had no idea how to do it), poor pay, unrealistic targets, forced overtime

headline: Accounting
pros: Fund Accounting, Trade Processing, Settlement & Reconcilaition
cons: Software development/Accuracy. Investigation, communication & Admin Support

headline: Poor management, no flexibility
pros: Entry level wage was good. Coworkers were good. Technology was ahead of the curve.
cons: Management did not support their employees and there was no scheduling flexibility for part time. Working their felt a little but like being back in high school.  Management was more worried about sales than customer service.

headline: SR FSR
pros: Hours are great for work/life balance
cons: Sales Targets are high and management wont support you.

headline: 9 years with CIBC
pros: My co-workers and direct manager were very supportive.  I also enjoyed helping the clients.
cons: Constant sales pressure.  I didn't have it in me to try to sell additional products to clients that they didn't need and the unrelenting questions about "how many calls" or "how many units" really got to me after awhile.  Didn't have supportive upper level management at the time I worked for the bank.  He didn't care about the peons down in the trenches!

headline: Disappointed about this company
pros:
Stock is doing good
20 word minimum
cons: All about making money, doesn't really care for employees, good experience but use employees as machines, all about lending. If your uncle or dad is working for the company then you get promote faster, if no then good luck. Manager is high school graduate, not professional at all but loyal to the company, i guess this is what they want. If you have a university degree you wouldn't want to stay with the company for more than 2 years. VERY VERY HIGH TURN OVER RATIO AND MANAGEMENT TEAM IS STILL PROUD OF THE COMPANY?!

headline: FSR II
pros: Training Process was OK some benefits
cons: The Hiring process was fast the training was good, but I got to meet one of the region executives for a quick visit and was very shocking!!! The way he express himself and the company’s way to make money to make his bonus, was beyond embarrassing and depressing I resigned a week after. There’s no such thing as “we’re here for the customers” “doing the right thing” that doesn’t exist in the companies book!! It’s all about LENDING!! And make more money for the Coe’s and executive’s bonus.  The branch was a disaster, including the managers who have no manager skills or ways to talk or encourage the employees. It was all about the calls and scripts and Calls, and lending lending!!  Not a very professional place to work and defiantly for a bank!!

headline: Not bad
pros: Great customers, enjoyed lending, ..
cons: Poor management, too much politics

headline: IT Specialist - ServiceNow Technical Admin
pros: Work from Home option is good
cons: low salary; will receive a post-coop-student paycheck only

headline: You can meet great people but upper management and company culture is toxic
pros: If you're lucky you can have a great manager and work with some great co-workers.
cons: they pay you the minimum and want to squeeze the life out of you, upper management doesn't give a damn and if you want to move up you have to actively seek opportunities, too many empty promises and little meaning for the pay you're given.

headline: Fairly Good
pros: Not micro managed by superiors
cons: Their pay scale could be higher

headline: CIBC values their employees, clients, and community.
pros: Best reason to work here is their benefits and company values of supporting the CBCF.
cons: Depending on which branch or area you work in, the office culture can differ drastically. This can hinder your personal growth.

headline: Lots of opportunities for the Bank to improve overall performance.
pros: Lots of training opportunities. Employees are encouraged to provide suggestions/recommendations. Time-off policies and benefits are somewhat comparable to other similar type organizations.
cons: The Senior Management needs to come up with a well thought out strategy and proper execution plan to achieve long term objectives. Many important projects/product launch are executed on a rush and end up with flaws after implementation that could have been easily avoided. The expectation of the management is to get more work done with less resources. The compensation is not competitive compared to the market.

headline: CIBC was a good employer that takes good care of their employees
pros: Fun environment, great team members, they accommodate ergonomic tools such as chairs desks keyboards etc
cons: They closed their Vancouver Call Center putting more than 200 employees out of work

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: Good working hours, and friendly staff
cons: working on weekends and rude customers

headline: Underpaid and overworked
pros: Great place to meet people, learn skills, and practice. Provides stable income while learning craft.
cons: Low wages, Challening to work with management on local and regional levels.

headline: great place to work with
pros: good for new graduate, lots of opptunity there
cons: you don't have privacy, pressure

headline: Good company with personal growth opportunities
pros: Great work life balance opportunities.
cons: The business is in a well regulated industry as a result there is a lot of overhead when it comes to completing even a simple task.

headline: Poor Comps
pros: Reputable Bank, Career Progression, Brand Name
cons: Work Stress, Long hours, Poor Comps

headline: Better then working at it shops
pros: 37.5 hours any additional hours are paid overtime
cons: Lot of politics among the employees

headline: Good place to start; limited growth potential
pros:
- Decent entry level salary and benefits
- Good place to learn brokerage business
- ability to move around
cons:
- Unstructured
- Questionable management

headline: CIBC - Traditional, Conservative
pros: Starting to catch up to the other FI's
cons: technology systems and employee programs/benefits lacking

headline: Lots of opportunities

headline: Great place to work with lots of room for advancement
pros:
- Such a large company that you can find new career opportunities without ever leaving.
- High standards for ensuring employee satisfaction and yearly targets for management to continuously improve on it.
- Common theme across the company is to promote individual growth.  To those on here who complain otherwise, look for a new position!  The groups that do not promote this are the minority and not reflective of CIBC as a whole.
- Majority of coworkers are pleasant and working for the best interests of everyone.
- Great work/life balance.  For those complaining otherwise, CONTACT HR!  CIBC has very strict overtime policies and if your management isn't obeying them then complain to the people who created them!
cons: - Lots of process as others have mentioned however it is for the benefit of everyone.  Being a financial institution requires tight controls over change to ensure uninterrupted business.  While process can be a pain in the rear end, it's a necessary evil in the financial industry.

headline: Culture and Leadership

A focused effort is required to continue to update systems and processes throughout various functions, the antiquated systems and processes will continue to frustrate highly transient talent.

headline: Terrible
pros:
If you are new to financial services, you will learn a ton of information regarding day-to-day banking, unsecured lending, secured lending, fixed-term investments, etc. Being someone who had very controlled finances throughout post-secondary, I was very unfamiliar with a lot of banking products so the information I absorbed was immense and beneficial both to my role and to myself.

The pay is also pretty good (starts at 39k with the ability to make a few thousand extra by the end of the year). Do not mistake it though, you are worked for every dollar you earn so don't think your work value has increased through this increase in pay.
cons:
The work environment is simply terrible. The managers are tyrannical and constantly micromanage employees. Positive reinforcement and constructive criticism is dismal at best, even when you are attaining your targets. The management will look for any excuse possible to maximize your output and cut into your wallet. This includes reprimanding your quarterly bonus due to a couple of lates no more than 5-10 minutes each. If you enjoy working for an organization that resembles the SS, look no further.

The call centre is constantly understaffed and poorly scheduled which means period of having one or two minutes in between calls to periods in which there are up to 70 calls waiting for your queue.

The management was overtly incompetent. The majority were not qualified for managerial roles (I doubt some even had a high school diploma let alone any sort of formal managerial education) and those that were, were often overlooked due to office politics. Affirmative action is rampant in CIBC's North York call centre, and I do not mean this in a good way. What it means is that a lot of people are hired unfortunately based on the colour of their skin rather than the content of their character and their qualifications for the role which ends up with CIBC becoming a victim of incompetent management. One manager at the North York call centre is even brave enough to show up to work daily with slurred speech and bloodshot eyes. I was subject to some forms of racial and ethnic discrimination in the work environment but due to the fact that I am a male of European origin, any sort of complaint against this was mocked by the management and human resources.

cons: Average new employee leaves CIBC within 4 months!!  This is their own statistic.  Extensively hire people immigrating to Canada (probably to hold them longer .. they loose their job and immigration can fall apart).  Low skill -- extensive use and training in "scripting" whereby you control client through conversation funneling - car dealers invented it.

headline: stressful

headline: Intense pressure to get Visa applications, outdated software interface that caused a multitude of problems.
pros: The only good reason to work at CIBC is to get experience to move on to a better banking position.
cons: Intense pressure to get Visa applications, outdated software interface that caused a multitude of problems.  Zero support from immediate management or higher management.  They seem to prefer female sheep who will follow rather than a person who is intelligent and can lead.  Software was the worst I have seen in any bank.  Tellers have no idea what most transactions are.  Managements number one solution is to "Call the internal help desk" when an employee does not know how to solve a problem.  The software uses codes, hundreds of them, to input things that are simple point and click "windows like" software at other banks I worked at.  Constant customer complaints and long customer lines.  Why do people still bank there?  Because its too much hassle to move accounts once you start.  I will never consider a position at CIBC again for any amount of money.

headline: Mixed bag.....

-Job Stability - as long as you achieve the basic activities your job is secure
-Good pay and benefits compared to alot of other employers
-Vacation time in your first year
-I am fortunate to have a very good manager
-Achievers recognition program - although very hard to earn
-Very competitive products and services 
-Can be proud to sell investments and mortgages as we offer best on the street
cons:
Focus is on sales - sometimes client experience comes second
-Of couse would like to make more money and earn more vacation,.... 
-Some managers are not good - unwilling to stand up to middle and upper manager on targets or goals that are un-attainable
-Bonuses could be bigger / and given quarterly 
-Removal of support roles in branch - more work being added onto staff that remain
-Outbound calls are a focus -- which I understand - but often calling the same clients over and over --- gets frustrating
-Company often looks outside own talent pool to higher outside the bank when they have qualified candidates
