headline: Amazing place to work, loved every second!
pros: Friendly environment, where everyone wants you to grow
cons: there was nothing i did not like

headline: Associate, Commercial Banking
pros: The company has good benefits, a fully funded pension, and a great employee share purchase plan.  The hours a fairly flexible within reason.
cons: The company has no direction.  The people making decisions at the top of the organization have no though for the impact on the staff, the customers or the image in the market.  They have no real training program in place for what is essentially a training role.  Anyone above the Senior Manager level is more concerned with passing the buck and protecting themselves than address problems and finding solutions.

headline: Big name but miser company
pros: Big Company just name only.
cons: HR . Managers are not allowed to give your reference even you have worked for 10 years. But when they hire you they always ask for it.

headline: Demanding workload, lack of appreciation from leadership, below industry pay
pros:
- Staff are all very friendly and supportive
- Opportunities to move around within CIBC
cons:
- No work life balance at some departments, with lack of respect for people's vacation
- Vacation payout from carry forward significantly less than equivalent work pay (not fair for employees to get "penalized" financially if they are not able to take vacation due to workload)
- Below industry salary (don't expect your salary/bonus will be much higher just because you're a work a lot harder than others or you are a high performer)

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Work life  balance
Good compensation
Support for peer group and management
Good Training
cons: Lower level management needs improvement

headline: Great
pros: Good work life balance. Great learning and growth opportunity
cons:
The salary could be more competitive. 
Senior Mgmt needs to be a little more considerate

headline: Not happy!
pros: Diversity, Pension, Top up parental leaves, stability, learning and plenty of time to finish tasks.
cons: Pay SUCKS and way below market, incompetent team (depends on teams), make you pay for work trips and pay back with useless TTC tokens (I don't use TTC!!!).

headline: Net Neutral
pros: Good facilities at flagsip branches, Imperial Service Platform
cons: Unpaid overtime an expectation, legacy systems, micro management style, net sales numbers, unrealistic targets, no work life balance

headline: Constant Sales Pressure
pros: Opportunity to move around with abundance of internal postings
cons: This position has constant sales pressure, so if sales is not your thing, then stay away. Pay does not match the amount of work. Organization culture, at least in my district, was unpleasant.

headline: FSR
pros: not too much presure, good co-worker
cons: not paid enough, some managers suck

headline: Worked as Business Systems Analyst
pros:
Great work environment
Benefit package
Career growth
cons: Overtime work may be required

headline: Unhappy place to work
pros: Great location, if you're in the downtown offices.
cons: Management doesn't place enough emphasis on employee happiness.  Offices often have broken chairs, dirty carpets & ugly furniture.  Employees are treated in a very "transactional" way.  Place has bad karma.  About 35% of workforce is simply ineffective.  Some people are way too busy while others never have any work to do.

headline: senior application deveploper
pros: good company,stable , in toronto
cons: salary is too low, for contractor wage is  too low

headline: Senior director
pros: Typical decent bank pay , not great but average
cons: Too much distrust. Staff refuse to make decisions so every decision goes upstairs. Takes a long time. Senior management very siloed and don't make total bank decisions.

headline: great culture but you have to move around  to move up
pros: Great culture, good people, well-known company, keep us fairly well informed
cons: not a lot of growth opportunities in all areas, can get redundant

headline: This is a great place to work and grow your career. Senior management is very supportive.
pros:
Supportive culture -- friendly atmosphere and great colleagues
Learning and development -- fully supported by senior management
Results oriented -- senior management routinely shares company results with employees
Community oriented -- great work by the company and its employees in communities across Canada
cons: Sometimes work-life balance can be a challenge

headline: Demanding but with high rewards
pros:
Teh Financial Services industry is central to the economy so what you work on matters.
You touch on many issues/aspects of business so your days are varied and you gain experience quickly.
Large organization presents many opportunities for career advancement
cons:
Challenging times mean change is constant.
Work can be stressful and require many hours outside the normal work hours.

headline: Risk adverse, slow to change
pros: If you work hard, there are lots of opportunities to move up and develop our career, adding to your resume.  You will also learn a lot.
cons: Culture of instant gratification based on hard numbers only.  Tendency t take the path of least resistance versus invest long term in the right behaviours to achieve long term results.

headline: Good to start career, good in resume
pros: Health Benefits, Year End Bonus, Employee Share Plan ...
cons:
Management, especially  People Managers lack emotional Intelligence. Very inept with responsibilities as people manager. the bank has good policies in place but mid-management is killing and ruining the bank's reputation as a good place to work.

- Management lacks accountability (most of them) this breeds distrust among employees.

headline: Unfortunate mass confusion.
pros: Your manager has no idea what you are doing.
cons:
Your manager has no idea what you are doing.
Lack of support.

headline: less stress, high job security
pros: laid back job, stable income, good work atmosphere
cons: no flexible hour, poor management, not enough feedback

headline: The United Nations of banking!
pros: Good learning opportunities with  lots of interaction with the culture of a city,
cons: Minimal growth opportunities. Support from management to grow is minimal

headline: customer service representative
pros: nothing really. i feel lucky because i have a good branch manager who leads the team well.
cons: have to promote products every single day which is stressful, pay really low for this position

headline: self-training, work "smart" to meet your sales target
pros: * one of the five largest banks in Canada and that is it
cons:
* poor training system/structure
* micro-management
* manager don't want you to voluntarily work over-time but they still demand you to achieve the sales target and compliance requirement

headline: There has to be better positions out there...
pros: Benefits , vacation, perks, banking discounts, groups to join within the organization
cons:
I can never take vacations when I want, it always seems conditional upon what other people with higher seniority are planning to do, even if they have not booked their vacation yet. 
Not much room for advancement and a lack of a supportive culture for advancement - most of the people in my office have been there for 10+ years and are not leaving anytime soon
Recognition given by management is very selective
Reward is given to those who work overtime, do not take any breaks, skip lunches all without compensation

headline: In CIBC being a team player, means you help everyone else, but no-one helps you
pros: Large organisation,stable,good benefits, various locations to work
cons: Inept management,to much empire building, focus changes every month, micromanagement is incredible. too much reporting which hinders productivity,to save money, CIBC cut back on training, hence higher turn over and costly errors."Squeaky wheel gets the grease' should be CIBC's motto, as the whiners are the ones that get noticed, those that put their heads down and work hard get ingnored. You  can obtain your sales quotas 90% of the time, not recognition, miss you quota one week,and you will be put on notice.

headline: The company itself is decent to work for but management needs to live the branch life.
pros: Hours are okay in the right branch.
cons: High selling pressures with an expectation to "do more do more do more". It is never enough.

headline: CIBC 111
pros: Great assistant manager and collegues. Friendly working environment
cons: High demand. No opportunity for moving up and low pay

headline: A rewarding place to work
pros:
Upward mobility is stong
Work life balance
cons:
Top leadership is weak
Low international presence

headline: Pretty good
pros:
-good opportunity to move up in company with good performance
- lots of different career opportunities
- very good benefits package
cons:
- tend to reward short term results 
- change direction too often
- not very focused on employee development

headline: Financial Service Representative  II
pros: Big company, good benefits, great people.
cons: stressful, demanding, unrealistic targets, poor training programs

headline: Excellent Experience
pros: Positive, supportive, teamwork, opportunity, results-driven
cons: Results-driven, support, opportunity, professional development

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Good working environment
Lots of opportunity for growth if you are a hard worker and know where you want to go
cons: Can be challenging if not a self-motivated individual

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to start a career
cons: Sales sometimes is very stressful

headline: very nice environment
pros: good relations with colleagues,stable and less presssing
cons: too stable to move up

headline: fine
pros: good company to work for
cons: lower paying of the major banks

headline: I have been warned before I started working here and regret ignoring those warnings.
pros: If you are with CIBC World Markets, the education perks are great.  They pay for quite a few courses from the Canadian Securities Institute and give you a bonus when you pass.
cons: Lack of advancement opportunities.  People with minimal education move up in to higher levels, yet I have seen individuals with an MBA remain in a salary band 4 position.  Wages are lower than other financial institutions.  There was a constant feeling of management out to keep everyone down, instead of looking out for their best interest.  I have worked for both Wood Gundy and the Retail Banking division.  This is the case in 3 out of the 3 offices I have worked at.

headline: The company is backwards, sideways and every which way other than straight forward.
pros: basic benefits of working for a major corporation such as benefits, vacation and relatively decent work hours.
cons: Management changes far too frequently, and as such shows no concerns nor respect for their direct reportrts. Management does not encourage, train or advance the development of employees, in my experience I actually saw management plot to terminate multiple employees on the basis they did not personally like them. I would advise looking at alternate places of employment.

headline: great
pros: good ppl and good enviroment
cons: the smallest of big five

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Year end bonus is decent (commercial banking)
cons: Sales Sales Sales - a manic focus for employees.

headline: Career Advancement is possible at CIBC
pros: Smart employees, good compensation, lots of career advancement opportunities
cons: Benefits are not as good, not a strong employee oriented culture

headline: high workload and stress for underwhelming pay
pros: benefits, 3 weeks holidays per year (FSR II and up)
cons: outdated impossible computer systems, underqualified leaders, high targets

headline: Sense of panic, can be linked to Market Vice President
pros: Have a genuine passion for what you are doing and people will notice. I have doubled my salary in 5 years.
cons: It may depend on the district or market you are working in, but if you have a panic-stricken leadership team, you may find yourself starting to believe it is more important to telemarket a prospective client, than it is to deal with one that is sitting in the lobby wanting to give you their business.

headline: ok
pros: hours, bonus, job security, benifits
cons: late hours, unreasonable quotas, pay

headline: FSR
pros: Good for new employee to learn on lending, and basic investing b/c you need to work on everything.
cons: Pay is the lowest compare to other big 5s

headline: Good place to work
pros: Strong Company --Client focused -Has always treated me well in the 14 years I have been there ---Good opportunity to move up
cons: Targets are aggressive ---Flexible hours are required if you want to do well----Keep changing how targets are measured

headline: fun and diversified work place....
pros:
- diversified work force.
- lots of career development opportunities.
- different career streams.  you can switch career stream without changing your seniority in the company.
cons:
- routine work hours.
- conservative.
- people tend to stay in the position for a long time, therefore, promotion opportunities is limited..
-

headline: I have been with CIBC for a year and a half
pros: People are really really nice.
cons: Salary is too low and some people are not knowledgable.

headline: Snooze Fest
pros: Managers are lazy so they don't stop by to check on you too often.
cons: People who don't follow compliance are kept because they exceed sales targets and bring business in.  This makes it hard to compete in a moral and ethical way.

headline: Wish I never moved to CIBC
pros: Some of your coworkers can make this place less painful
cons:
High targets
Poor management
Cold calling
Hard to move anywhere
Horrible pay

headline: CIBC has been an experience where I have been able to grow and develop both, at a professional and personal level.
pros: CIBC offers an atomosphere with several opportunities for growth; excellent team management by supervisors; great recognition for hard work; welcomes diverse backgrounds and overall, an outstanding sense of value for each employee.
cons: Rigid vacation policies without much scope for emergency events. However, HR has several supporting programs to help you as an employee.

headline: Poor
pros: Good work life balance for employees
cons: Management isn't very experienced for title

headline: Good experience and friendly collegues
pros: Managers are very understandable and experienced.
cons: Pays salaries to employees and after 4 months requests for portion of it back, reason - overpayment. Not organized at all.

headline: Manager, CIBC
pros: Good compensation and benefits, opportunity for advancement
cons: Long hours, high sales targets

headline: Great!!
pros: good shifts, good remuneration, understanding staff and superiors, helpful and I learned a lot from my experience there.
cons: I cant think of any cons to be honest, it had definitely been a while since I left and from what I remember it was great!

headline: CIBC is a good company to work
pros: Diversified culture, respect employee, flexibible working hour
cons: Salary & benefit are under average

headline: Advisory Application Developer
pros: It is lead position but it is still qualify overtime
cons: Sometime this job didn't has similar role like managment level with less pay

headline: Business Development Manager
pros: Was left alone to do the job.  This is great if you want to avoid micro-managers and if you have what it takes to work independently.  Lot of upward mobility.
cons: Didn't have enough work to do, but was still expected to deliver a certain level of results.  This put unnecessary pressure on me.

headline: Associate
pros: Good place to work for
cons: Not Enough Opportunity to avail

headline: Great work life balance
pros:
1. Great work life balance
2. Better salary than other banks
3. Excellent work culture and very supportive support staff.
cons:
1. Very outdated technology systems. 
2. Large and slow org. For sure there is room for improvement and it can be lot more efficent. 
3. Need improvements in the hiring process.
4. Less opportunities for career advancement

headline: Underpaid
pros: high base than competitors. variety of product is high. all in one management.
cons:
micro management
too many focus all at once

headline: Really depends on the department you're working at
pros: Decent benefits, company culture at head office roles is less political and more open and welcoming than at some other FIs.
cons: At the retail banking level, horrible job at hiring for people management roles - vision is very short-sighted and short-term performance based

headline: Fun for a bank
pros: The teams within CIBC eChannels strive to be innovative, collaborative, and productive. Managers are encouraging and try to provide as much opportunities and resources as they can. When new ideas for employee satisfaction get brought up (such as open wifi network), the management shows effort to make it happen.
cons: Due to the nature of the organization, security is a big concern, which causes the lines of communication to be less than open. Also, a lot of tedious bureaucratic and administrative processes are enforced, which are. The organization is highly structured and hierarchical. In general, people have great work-life balance - most people go home at 5 to attend to kids, etc.

headline: It is a day in life at work
pros: Good investment products, strict bank..
cons: policies are implemented without thought as how would it impact each department under the organization hiearchy

headline: Met the best bosses and the worst... However, the good people still outnumbered the bad, keep your head up and focus!
pros: Promotion opportunities seem to be readily available as long as you qualify.
cons: It seems like our office is always under-staffed, which means everybody is overloaded with work.  This really decreases job satisfaction as you are drown by the daily miscellaneous things and so caught up that you are not having a chance to breath and absorb all that you learn.  Also, taking a vacation seems very challenging to coordinate with when it comes to coverage.

headline: financial advisor
pros: decent income, good coworkers, great for retail middle class bank, good autonomy, great return on asset for shareholder and upper management
cons: domestic bank, old systems in branches, not well equipped offices, unrealistic objectives, smallest of the big 5

headline: sucked hated going into work
pros: benefits were above average given
cons: low salary compared to others

headline: cibc it department review senior developer
pros: very good work environment , and good trainning
cons: less challenges in the work

headline: Leadership with tactical expertise but not equipped with strategic vision
pros: Great co-workers, laid back atmosphere, team spirit
cons: Poor leadership with a rudderless journey

headline: God help you if you work there
pros: Nothing to brag about at all.
cons: High expactation, low pay, lack of HR presence to whatch what is happining at the branch level. none of any of the HR planning or analysis implemented or exericesed. No effecicent training, nor an effective plan. Bunch of clowns, all what they have are orders for each day for sales people to reach in sales target. And who pays the price? the poor customers that do not understand the products being shoved in their throats.

headline: Financial Representative
pros:
- Friendly environment
- Benefits
- Good balance of work and life
cons: Compentation doesn't seem fair for the duties performed

headline: Good experience but need a bigger challenge
pros:
Learn a lot about the banking world
Downtown location, and travel costs can always be expensed
Great managers and support
Really great work life balance - if you chose to leave at the regular time or if you chose to stay, it was the same, as long as you finished your work
cons:
Not a lot of cooperation between departments
Not enough ownership for mistakes
Everyone blames other people for mistakes
No structure or direction
No big challenge or innovation

headline: working at CIBC
pros: 40k a year as financial service rep.  3 weeks vacation after one year. financial assistance for further education.  health benefits
cons: very political and very high expectations.

headline: Everything you expected working as a client service respresentative
pros: Great benefits, manager & assistant manager were very considerate, great people,
cons: pressure to meet quotas, job can get mundane

headline: good place
pros:
one of the big 5
has a name in the industry
has a world-wide reputation
the existence of many atm machines which provides good accessibility for client's cash needs. 
great talent acquisition
high starting salary
cons: you will need to work long working hours if you want to suceed in your job as with any other job.

headline: great entry level position
pros: This is a very salary benefits, secure position which one can build their experience and grow as a Young banker
cons: long complicated hiring process and a lower wage rate then alot of other commission only based positions

headline: Excellent
pros: Good finanancial institution to work.  Rewards its employees.  Very much engaged with community activities and its a great pride to work for such institutions.
cons: Salary and Compensation stucture still very old style and need to bring it up to today's standard.

headline: Generally, a solid company to work for.
pros: Good balance of work and life
cons: Compensation does not reflect performance as it should.

headline: Good Place to work
pros: On the IT related job positions CIBC will allow you for some balance between work and personal life as long as deadlines are meet. Lots of opportunities to learn and gain experience along with liberty to propose and research for solutions to improve the infrastructure
cons: Politics are involved to a high degree in the relations between different parts of the organization. Wished or not there are silos in which each manager/director will set their own managing style. Some nice some not that nice.

headline: new employee to CIBC last 2 years
pros:
espp benefits Competitive pay friendly peers
team effort
culture
diversity
stability
cons:
corporate ladder tough to climb, many jobs are "spoken for"
create contact within different areas to help climb the ladder

headline: Movement within is hard depending on position
pros:
- lots of self-help materials
- work/life balance is high
cons: - difficult to jump jobs

headline: Strong Leadership at top, poor management philosophy at operational levels.
pros:
Good self help corporate training resources.
Average salaries.
cons:
Poor Management at operational levels. 
Poor career development and tuition reimbursement policies.

headline: Think twice before you accept this job
pros: good branch hours, good branch locations, got to meet some great colleagues, good system to perform require tasks, good support help desk
cons: favoritism, favoritism, favoritism!!! senior management has no idea what they're doing, micromanaging, minimal training, salary low compared to other FI, products not competitive, limited community presence, staff not properly trained

headline: Great employer, however, management selection process weak.
pros: Stable employer with economies of scale.  Employee annual school reimbursement program meets competition.
cons: Can be treated like a number if your immediate management is treating their own job as a stop gap position.

headline: Financial Service Ambassador
pros: Easy to get job there, looks good on resume, benefits are ok
cons: Poor pay, they do not encourage growth or development, management does not know what is going in branches, they care more about sales than customer service, worst job I have ever had

headline: Good working environment, efforts would be valued
pros: Management are supportive in terms of escalation within the company. Efforts would be valued and recognize.
cons: Low pay compared to other brokerage firms.

headline: On the sales side, a blend of managers who don't know what they're doing and some lucky hires
pros: Stable job with good benefits, potential for internal promotions
cons: a lot of micromanaging and obsession with having to put a number on everything. You definitely feel like just a number working for a bank and they have no problem reminding you that you're replaceable.

headline: dead end job
pros:
great if you are still in school studying
great if you are looking for a job that you do not have to worry about leaving the office
cons:
not very high for advancement
management is trying to revamp and revitalize employees motivation but they make workers wait too long before advancement

headline: For the teller positions (across the board)
pros: You get all your banking fees reduced
cons:
-work long hours
-dont get your OT
-get paid just over min wage, while risking your life with robbers out there (our CIBC was robbed)

headline: fsr
pros:
good benefits
good team, work environment
cons: The job is very repetitive

headline: Cibc review on employement
pros:
Learn a lot
room to grow
cons: schedule flexiblity when you first start is not good

headline: they will usew you until you gain fulltime employment
pros: decent trust with long tenured company
cons: NO promotion from within unless they feel you are not going anywhere

headline: Back stabbing culture and fear based senior leadership
pros:
- Decent compensation
- Free coffee / tea
- Downtown Toronto
- 9-5 culture
cons:
- Culture of 'busy bodies' that backstab people. Trying to get colleagues fired seems to be a hobby of most people at this organization.
- Inflated job titles. Someone who would be called a Manager somewhere else is called a Director at CIBC. A Sr. Consultant is a Sr. Manager. This has caused small people to feel they are big and important. They feel entitled to be respected and get upset when new hires don't respect a 27 year old "Sr. Mgr". Ridiculous. 
- Sr. Leadership are incredibly two faced and rule by intimidation. Being honest with your own manager is career suicide at this place.

headline: Pros and Cons to Working at CIBC
pros: Company allows horizontal and vertical moves. Productive, Fun, Supporting team, good environment to work with. My manager is an angel. Amazing hands on manager who is extremely supportive yet will give it to you straight.
cons: This company unfortunately falls short on its ability to provide a fair equitable workplace in some instances allowing employees to carry on without proper and fair compensation for jobs taken on as temporary assignment or temporary basis.

headline: My experience was horrible
pros: no pro about the cmpany
cons: company rewards poor team work and difficult personalities

headline: A good place to launch career
pros: security of a big bank. CIBC is expanding, so there are many opportunities I can move on to in the  next few years.
cons:
some computer software is old. In the process of upgrading though. 
Saturday rotational schedule and extended business hours make schedule a little odd. However this is still much better than TD. TD opens till 8pm during the week, and 7 days a week. Not sure how TD employees manage their personal lives with a schedule like that.

headline: An amazing bank with many opportunities and diversity
pros: great corporate culture, options to move up
cons: highly sales driven and hard to network with coworkers

headline: Fun
pros: People are fun and helpful when needed
cons: Work is unorganized and training is non-existent

headline: It's Ok
pros: Stable job,immigrants have a chance to be promoted
cons: Same as with any other bank,Your responsibility is bigger then your salary

headline: Say good bye to your family and friends
pros:
Decent benefits
Child-like incentives can be fun (ie: mini-put)
Occasionally you are able to truly help someone
cons:
Low wages
Insane hours, you will most likely be the only person you know working the hours you will work
You need to steer a conversation from an online banking password reset to a mortgage sale
Minimal advancement opportunities
Chairs that do not function

headline: career with cibc
pros: no growth in this company. high stress level. wages are not good.
cons: there are hardly any positive thing about this bank.

headline: Investment Representative CIBC
pros:
godd environment good coleagues
they hire anyone
cons:
low pay extra work
no recognition
harsh punishmnet for errors

headline: good
pros: great team members, laid back yet assertive and demanding manager made the job more interesting and challenging
cons: Sometimes dealing with oblivious customers can be a bit nerve wrecking and stressful

headline: One of the best places to work for!
pros:
The management recognizes talent and moves people to more suited roles where possible!
Understanding management team, that knows you have a family!
Good opportunities available to cross train, move functions and of course move up !
cons: None that I can see :)

headline: 2nd time around.  Positive changes in corporate direction
pros:
Very focused with respect to plan and execution
Fair compensation and incentive package
Great working environment
Conscious of needs of all employees
cons:
Middle management doesn't always have the toolset to be qualified managers.
Training programs don't always focus on carreer building and tend to be generic in nature.
Communication from the top is lacking during projects.
Poor management and execution of large initiatives

headline: Highly disorganized, however typical of a large company...
pros:
Opportunities to move up quickly into middle management 
Large company - opportunity to work in a variety of teams and lines of business
cons:
Lack of desire for change and improvement
Constant changes in org structures causes distruption 
Poor work/life balance
Highly political environment - leaders are "self serving" rather than on doing the what is right for clients
A lot of outsourcing of technology and HR functions overseas - risk to job security
Extremely Aggressive targets in the sales force (branch and call centre
Managers blame their subordinates for errors rather than take responsibility - you really have to be careful to "CYA", however lack of trust also leads to poor relationships and partnership across lines of business
Very few women in executive positions

headline: Best training program and always recognize hard working employee
pros:
-give enough training for any position in the company
-always recognize hard working employee
-positive enviroment
cons: -management need to know more technique of managing people

headline: general accountant
pros: good location, friendly working environment,
cons: long days, should be 100% accurate at work.

headline: CIBC
pros: One of the few jobs with a pension.  Good for people with excellent interpersonal skills.  No overnight shifts. No Sundays. Statutory holidays off. Inclusive environment (gays can be openly gay, the teller line often looks like the United Nations)   The glass ceiling is for most women with children not until you get to the district manager level.
cons:
Outdated badly maintained technology and internal programs.  Very poor training "trial by fire" . 
Do not expect the job to be 9 to 5 many financial service representative start at 8 work as late as 7:30 and often work saturdays.  You will need to supplement your pension as it has an accrual rate of 0.8% per year compared to government/teacher of 2% per year.

headline: Good work Exp, not so much for management and support.
pros:
Lots of room to grow in the company
Friendly co-workers
cons:
Very old internal systems, which is a headache to get used to.
Discouraging Managers

headline: Very stressful, unrealistic goals
pros: Great benefits, discounts on financial services, paid sick leave, maternity top, employee share purchase plan, short term disability coverage, paid training
cons: Stressful target based job with goals often set so high that frequently no one makes quota. Instead of celebrating success, a huge focus is placed on failure. It is a very discouraging environment to work in. Often do not feel I have the tools I need to meet client expectations.

headline: Dissatisfying experience with middle management
pros: Guaranteed weekend and holidays off, co-workers were pleasant and work with.  located in a great metropolitan city of Toronto, diverse community; exposures to other ethnic groups and cultures.
cons: Little assist for employees to advice their careers at the company, very difficult to transfer to other departments that were not directly related to your current role.

headline: Limited career growth at CIBC
pros: Good people. Great learning place.
cons: Low salary. No career development.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Really takes care of employees, co-workers are great. Culture overall is still conservative as expected.
cons: Pay is not the greatest and the vacation is just standard.

headline: its all about the money
pros: were able to build a new division quickly, bringing in good talent
cons: lacked a moral compass to provide direction; willing to throw talent and money at projects that lacked leadership and direction

headline: Overworked and under paid
pros:
Great employees
Meet a lot of new  people
Career growth up to management
cons:
Pay is horrible
Overworked and underpaid

headline: Good company, nice corporate culture
pros: Nice people, good corporate culture, good benefits
cons: Lack of clear communication from senior leadership

headline: not so good
pros: reputation for working at Captial Market
cons: Disorganized and lack of communication. A market follower

headline: Overall, satisfied.
pros: Benefits, good place for women to advance.
cons: Volume of work, it can be difficult to manage. The expectation to do more with less.

headline: Treated like a widget and not a human being
pros: Established company, decent benefits, decent pension plan, great senior management.
cons: The problems begin at the Executive level.  They've established unrealistic targets with absolutely useless technology.  The workload is unbearable and most of the underwriters are on burn out.  Morale amongst employees is at the absolute lowest I've ever seen it. The Mortgage underwriter position is one of the worst jobs at CIBC.  Underwriters were laid off in Calgary yet the sales force has increased and they constantly complain about service levels being to slow to remain competitive.  Basically underwriters have a bigger pool of deals to underwrite but less employees to do so.  New technology  was introduced with little or no benefit, saturday shifts were introduced with no real increase in revenue, only to copy TD bank.  The bank is totally reactive and doesn't know how to retain talent. Recently many employees have left for greener pastures. The pay is poor in comparison to the job demands and most underwriters work an excessive amount of hours in order to meet their unmanageable daily targets.  The sales force has absolutely no training program to train new sales staff and most of the underwriters have to essentially train new sales staff on top of all their other job demands.  The technology the underwriters are given is slow and inefficient yet the tasks they are required to do only increase each year. A work life balance is totally frowned upon.  It would be nice to have the option to work from home every once and awhile but due to the poor technology that is impossible.  Underwriters are totally kept in the dark and are only made aware of significant changes at the last possible second.  Management isn't helpful because they also seemed overworked and constantly stressed.  Feedback is non existent, unless a mistake is made at which point coaching is offered.

headline: all around poor employer
pros:
location - down town Toronto
free banking
employee share purchase plan
free stationary
i'm presuming that the benefits plan is comparable to most other fi's?
cons:
-lack of vision from sr management - as in nothing
-as opposed to taking small constructive steps in improving processes, technology etc, this bank attempts to change everything at once - with always less than half a concerted effort and always unsuccessfully
-communication from upper management is negligible to non-existent
-compensation relative to competition is extremely poor
-hiring practices are atrocious - not sure how certain individuals are promoted - i'm fairly certain  that experience is not taken into account
- i cannot name one manager above me that is competent, approachable or even has a real grasp of what is going on on a daily basis
- cibc does not encourage growth from within and will quite often stymie competent and productive employees from growing
- no investment in training is provided to the staff
- archaic technology
- at the beginning of 2012 - they literally stated that the bank wishes to be #4 in mortgages.  i cannot for the life of me begin to comprehend why any institution in any industry would not strive be the best
- as much as the bottom line matters in all industries, this bank ONLY looks at the bottom and has no focus on employee morale, employee growth and development or the fostering of an entrepreneurial environment where individuals are encouraged to provide productive and constructive ideas to better the work environment

headline: Satisfactory but no support from senior management
pros: Flexible hours afforded to me in case of emergency
cons: No support from superior on career advancement

headline: Good pay, your job satisfaction will be heavily dependent your reporting manager
pros: The PBR role pays well for the amount of work you do or the complexity involved, and variable compensation(bonus) is quite generous in comparison to what the FSRs get at CIBC branches.
cons: lack of compliance exists at PCF.

headline: Overall positive but time for a change
pros:
Blue chip corporation
Banking benefits 
sdsdf sdfsdf
cons:
Inter-departmental politics
Lack of any training and consistency for senior management
Overly bureaucratic

headline: Looks great on resume, good place to learn
pros:
Looks good on resume
Good information sharing and learning encouraged
Potentially interesting in right departments
Good communication lines to management
Being proactive is encouraged
cons:
Dated technology all around with strict rules about deviating from preapproved list
Hardcore bureaucracy in all areas which results in hypocrisy and frustration
Slow moving behemoth, unwilling to change even when clearly presented with better solutions that remedy existing problems
Too much corporate BS and empty talk, often feels like you're on an episode of "The Office"
Aggressive firewall and machine lockdown
Clear preference for importing resources from oversees to save money
Very adhoc and chaotic at times, poorly designed business processes and unwillingness to alter them, which creates very bad professional habits
Information overload - constantly bombarded with irrelevant information for your tasks. Have to create email filters or you'll spend 2/3 of your time reading stuff that doesn't relate to you

headline: Good Entry Roll
pros:
Great Entry position
Competitive Salary for the first job
Lots of Training Opportunities from supporting manager
cons: Has lower salary range compare to other banks

headline: Avoid working for CIBC
pros: The co-workers I had were very nice and helpful. Scheduling was flexible but only due to co-workers' willingness to accommodate, not due to management flexibility
cons: The company does not invest in its employees and doesn't want to grow talent from within. The management constantly puts employees under high stress and only uses the "stick" approach. High performers are not recognized. The benefits are getting worse every year. The salary is lower in comparison to similar positions at other banks. The training process is terrible and technology is outdated. The company is not interested in any feedback from its employees.

headline: Not a terrible place to work, but high performing employees need to recognized more.
pros:
Work life balance is generally fair.
Benefits are reasonably good, banking benefits in particular.
Company is involved in several charities.
cons:
High performing employees are often not recognized for their work or are denied internal promotions due to HR "policies".
Salary is not very good relative to other companies (for technology at least).
Management often not very knowledgeable about the team and/or technology they are in charge of.

headline: It was a learning experience
pros: It is a wholesome corporation that is trying hard to increase market share and results.  It is a respectable company and makes employees proud to work for them,
cons: Career advancement is not made easy nor encouraged.  CIBC prefers to keep employees at current positions rather than help them advance onto other positions or departments.

headline: Good for a summer.
pros:
Flexible part time hours. 
Lots of locations to work. 
Good exposure to different kinds of attitudes. 
Helps give a basic understanding of banking world.
cons:
Management play(ed) favorites. 
Not flexible for time off [for studies]
Company is not proactive in developing talent
Company is bad at retention of student employees (I now work at RBCCM)

headline: Great work, great management
pros: Best regional boss possible with fair income and good benefit with bonus packages. Good working environment for long term employment.
cons: Long hours were the norm but that was okay by me. Working for large corporate was not as enjoyable as a smaller company

headline: good experience, new to banking so it provides me great opportunity for advancement
pros: great benifits, good staff moral, great leadership, good people that promote work life balance, tried to work extra hours to be exceptional as i come from a large city work ethic and they told me to go home, i couldnt believe what i heard
cons: salary compared to other banks for same position, technology well behind

headline: Great job with potential to grow, and good diversity.  Also no parking available.
pros: It fosters professional development however they are very strict with punctuality.  Moreover, great opportunities for work life balances with several programs such as fitness on site, charity events, diversity events and fundraising.
cons: Very strict attendance.  High targets are also employed.  Also, the parking is an issue here.  There is no parking available at all. It is also the lowest paying bank

headline: It is a decent place to work
pros: Good manager at the branch that I am working at.  The manager is very willing to teach me although I know that this is not the case in all the branch.
cons: Upper management is stupid, they always implement changes that does not make sense.  In order to compete with other FIs, they create the stupidest policies.   Example:  only home branch account opening will count as sales... serving IBB clients does not help you meet target.  Is that stupid and yet they want us to provide excellent customer service.. hahaha good luck IBB clients, I need to ensure that I serve home branch clients only :)

headline: perfect
pros: challenge satisfied harmony comfortable funny
cons: stressful low salary tight long working time

headline: It was an overall satisfactory experience
pros: I found the people I worked with, i.e., my co-workers, to have high caliber moral and integrity.  During the time I worked there - it was like a familial relationship.
cons: Lack of presence in the US.  CIBC is largely a Canadian company and their US presence is minimal.

headline: CIBC is a place which offers a lot of opportunity to move up and succeed with passion!
pros: Enjoyable workplace, very friendly co workers, cheerful, motivated people and strong leadership among colleagues. As said before in my review headline, CIBC is a place of opportunity, you will learn a lot. It is not just a simple job, it is a FUN career!
cons: There are actually none for now, although CIBC could possibly improve on installing better desks and chairs for the employees. Besides that, everything is just perfect!!!

headline: The emperor has no clothes
pros: The imperial service in it's truest form is a really excellent offer... It has been diluted and now a visa is as important as a financial plan
cons: No one wants to hear what needs to be change just do more and hope to gain market share who cares about the employee eexperience.

headline: good place to work
pros: a lot of grouth opportunity, clear requirements, good benefts
cons: old comp sistem, luck of trenning support

headline: It was good.
pros: Growth was good and also the salary.
cons: Rude co-workers and bosses made it a hostile environment.
